agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This board adjudicates contract performance and compensation disputes; the bill's clarifications regarding the recovery of costs for replacement contractors will directly impact the legal standards used in such disputes.

The Treasurer serves on the Board of Public Works and manages the State Insurance Trust Fund; the bill's clarification of liability limitations for damage to real and tangible personal property is highly relevant to this office.

The OAG provides legal counsel to all state agencies and reviews contracts for compliance; the bill also explicitly references the OAG's role as the state's primary legal counsel in its prohibited provisions section.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires State or State-aided or controlled entities to include a requirement in maintenance contracts that prime contractors procure janitorial products from Blind Industries and Services of Maryland (BISM) if those products are packaged or repackaged by BISM and are available.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland State procurement units and State-aided or controlled entities
qa_results.stakeholders: Blind Industries and Services of Maryland (BISM), prime contractors on State maintenance contracts, and small business janitorial supply subcontractors.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is not anticipated to have a direct effect on State finances, though it may have a minimal operational effect on State procurement units. There is no expected material impact on local governmental finances. Small businesses that currently provide janitorial supplies as subcontractors or suppliers on State maintenance contracts may see a meaningful negative impact as procurement shifts to BISM.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the primary operational support and central procurement authority for the state, DGS is directly responsible for the planning and maintenance of state-owned facilities and overseeing procurement contracts, including those for janitorial services affected by this bill.
DBM is the principal fiscal agency and supervises budget execution and procurement policies; it was specifically identified in the fiscal note as a source of information for this bill's impact.

The Board of Public Works oversees and approves significant state procurement contracts and expenditures, and would be responsible for ensuring that the procurement preferences for Blind Industries and Services of Maryland are upheld in state contracts.

MDOT manages extensive state-owned facilities, including airports, transit stations, and office buildings, which require significant housekeeping and janitorial contracts subject to the bill's requirements.
The Department of Health operates various public health facilities and state-run hospitals that utilize janitorial services and products covered under the expanded procurement preference.

As a large state entity with numerous campuses and facilities, the University System of Maryland is a significant consumer of janitorial services and supplies impacted by the prime contractor requirements in the bill.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Small, Minority & Women Business Affairs
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This office monitors socioeconomic procurement programs; since the bill expands preferences for a preferred provider (BISM) which may impact the availability of subcontracts for small or minority businesses, it is relevant to their oversight mission.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: DPSCS manages numerous correctional facilities that require large-scale maintenance and janitorial supplies, making them a major user of the contracts affected by this preference.

The Comptroller serves on the Board of Public Works, which oversees state contracts, and as the state's chief financial officer, is involved in the approval and auditing of state expenditures related to procurement.
The State Treasurer is a member of the Board of Public Works, which must approve and monitor the procurement contracts impacted by these changes in preference rules.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes the Maryland Inventory of Cemeteries and Burial Sites Workgroup to study and make recommendations regarding the creation and maintenance of a statewide cemetery inventory system, including standardizing definitions, evaluating existing documentation practices, and estimating implementation costs.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Historical Trust
qa_results.stakeholders: Local governments, genealogical and historical organizations, descendant communities, religious and private cemetery owners, and state preservation agencies.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: General fund expenditures increase by $42,200 in FY 2026 only for the Maryland Historical Trust to hire one contractual staffer to support the workgroup. There is no local fiscal impact.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill requires the Maryland Historical Trust, which is a unit within the Department of Planning, to provide the primary staffing for the workgroup. Additionally, the Director of the Maryland Historical Trust is a designated member of the workgroup.

The Maryland Office of Cemetery Oversight is housed within the Department of Labor. The Executive Director of that office is a workgroup member, and the Secretary of Labor is responsible for appointing several additional members from local, historical, and religious organizations.

The Maryland State Archivist (or their designee) is a mandated member of the workgroup, reflecting the agency's role as the central depository for government and historical records that may pertain to burial sites.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill creates a new temporary entity (the Maryland Inventory of Cemeteries and Burial Sites Workgroup) that fits exactly within this classification of specialized state-mandated task forces.

The Chief of the Office of Cultural Resources within the Maryland Department of Transportation is a designated member of the workgroup, as MDOT manages land and infrastructure projects that often interact with historical burial sites.

The fiscal note indicates that the Office of the Attorney General will handle legal research and analysis associated with the workgroup's responsibilities, such as reviewing definitions of 'cemetery' and 'burial site' in the Maryland Annotated Code.
The fiscal note identifies a general fund expenditure of approximately $42,200 in FY 2026 for contractual staffing, which falls under the oversight of DBM for budget development and execution.

The workgroup is required to report its findings and recommendations to the Governor by December 1, 2025, and the Governor oversees the executive departments tasked with staffing and supporting the workgroup.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill increases the maximum amount of wine that a holder of a barbershop or beauty salon beer and wine license in Frederick County may serve to a customer for on-premises consumption from 5 ounces to 6.5 ounces per glass.
qa_results.responsible_party: Frederick County Board of License Commissioners
qa_results.stakeholders: Barbershop and beauty salon owners and customers in Frederick County
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no state fiscal impact and is not expected to materially affect Frederick County finances or operations.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the head of the executive branch, the Governor's Office is responsible for signing the bill into law and oversees the administration of state laws and regulations.

The Comptroller is responsible for regulating the alcohol industry in Maryland and overseeing the collection of related revenues, making the alteration of alcoholic beverage licenses relevant to its regulatory functions.

The bill's licensing requirements are tied to the possession of barbershop and beauty salon permits issued under the Business Occupations and Professions Article, which is overseen by the Department of Labor.
The bill amends the Alcoholic Beverages and Cannabis Article of the Maryland Code, which is the primary statutory title containing the regulatory framework for both industries overseen by the state.
The OAG serves as the chief legal officer for the state, providing counsel on the interpretation and enforcement of changes to the Annotated Code of Maryland.

qa_results.bill_summary: Starting January 1, 2027, this bill prohibits keeping an individual rooster movement-constrained through the use of an enclosure or tether, with certain exceptions for commercial poultry producers, schools, animal shelters, and youth agricultural programs. It establishes that violations are civil offenses subject to warnings and fines, and authorizes the Maryland Department of Agriculture to adopt regulations while local animal control and law enforcement handle enforcement.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Agriculture, State and local law enforcement, and local animal control authorities
qa_results.stakeholders: Individual rooster owners, commercial poultry producers, public and nonpublic schools, animal welfare organizations, members of 4-H and Future Farmers of America, and local animal control agencies.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund revenues may increase minimally from civil penalties, which include a warning for the first offense, up to $500 per rooster for a second offense, and up to $1,000 per rooster for subsequent offenses. State enforcement is expected to be managed within existing resources. Local government expenditures for law enforcement and animal control may increase minimally to enforce the new restrictions.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill was originally introduced as part of the Agriculture Article and addresses poultry (roosters) and avian flu, which are within the department's purview. The final bill mandates that 'The Department' (referring to Agriculture in this context) adopt regulations and authorizes it to coordinate with law enforcement for enforcement.
The bill explicitly authorizes any State law enforcement officer to enforce the new restrictions on keeping roosters and the associated civil penalties.
The bill establishes a new civil offense with associated warnings and tiered financial penalties, which will be processed and adjudicated through the state court system.

As the chief legal officer for the state, the OAG provides counsel to the Department of Agriculture on the creation of regulations and represents the state in matters related to the enforcement of the Criminal Law article.
Public and non-public schools that receive state funds are specifically exempted from the bill's restrictions on keeping roosters.

Members of 4-H programs are exempt from the bill's restrictions provided they meet specific documentation requirements. 4-H is administered by the University of Maryland Extension, part of the University System of Maryland.

The fiscal note indicates a potential increase in general fund revenues due to the civil penalty provisions; the Comptroller is responsible for the collection of state revenues and management of the general fund.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill updates the laws governing the State Board of Chiropractic Examiners by altering board membership appointment methods, revising educational and examination requirements for licensure, and replacing extern licenses with a preceptorship and temporary licenses. It also expands the Board's disciplinary authority, allowing it to conduct unannounced office inspections for infection control violations and require licensees to submit to health examinations if they pose a potential harm to patients.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland State Board of Chiropractic Examiners
qa_results.stakeholders: Chiropractors, chiropractic license applicants, chiropractic students, and Maryland consumers of chiropractic services.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill's requirements are expected to be handled within existing budgeted resources. There is a potential minimal increase in general fund revenue from civil fines (up to $5,000 per violation). Special fund expenditures may decrease slightly due to the removal of newspaper advertising requirements for examinations, while other costs, such as Board-mandated health examinations, are expected to be minimal. Specific total dollar estimates are not provided in the Fiscal Note.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The State Board of Chiropractic Examiners is a unit within the Department of Health. The bill extensively revises the board's regulatory framework, licensure qualifications, and inspection authorities, and requires the board to adopt new regulations for preceptorships and infection control.

The Governor is responsible for appointing the members of the State Board of Chiropractic Examiners. The bill alters the requirements for the nomination list submitted to the Governor and introduces an alternative method for candidates to provide statements of nomination.

The Office of Appointments assists the Governor in recruiting and vetting candidates for state boards. This bill changes the criteria and nomination process for selecting the five chiropractor members of the State Board of Chiropractic Examiners.

The OAG serves as legal counsel to state boards and commissions. It will be involved in advising the Board on the implementation of expanded disciplinary grounds, the new authority to conduct unannounced inspections, and the legal protocols for requiring health examinations of licensees.

The OAH adjudicates contested administrative cases for state agencies. The bill references the hearing provisions under the Health Occupations Article for disciplining licensees, which are conducted by independent Administrative Law Judges at the OAH.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill requires applicants for temporary chiropractic licenses to submit to a criminal history records check (CHRC). These checks are processed by the Criminal Justice Information System Central Repository (CJIS-CR) within this department.
The bill authorizes the Board to impose civil penalties of up to $5,000 for certain violations, which the fiscal note confirms are deposited into the State's General Fund, managed by the Comptroller.
As the principal fiscal agency, DBM is responsible for supervising the budget execution and personnel aspects of state agencies, including the Department of Health and its regulatory boards.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill allows qualifying veterans' organizations in Anne Arundel County to convert their Class C beer, wine, and liquor licenses to a specific Class C (veterans' organization) license. It reduces the annual fee for this license from $400 to $300, permits Sunday sales without an additional permit, and allows the local licensing board to offer application and administrative fee discounts.
qa_results.responsible_party: Anne Arundel County Board of License Commissioners
qa_results.stakeholders: Veterans' organizations in Anne Arundel County that hold or apply for Class C alcoholic beverages licenses.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: According to the Fiscal Note, Anne Arundel County revenues are estimated to decrease by 2,400 annually starting in fiscal 2026. This decrease results from lower annual license fees and the elimination of the requirement for a separate 120 dollar Sunday sales permit for eligible veterans' organizations. There is no impact on State revenue or expenditures.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Comptroller of Maryland is the state's principal regulator of the alcohol industry. This bill amends the Alcoholic Beverages and Cannabis Article to alter license types, fees, and operating hours in Anne Arundel County, which falls under the regulatory purview of the Comptroller's office at the state level.

The bill specifically targets veterans' organizations by creating a conversion process for their liquor licenses and reducing their annual fees. This is directly relevant to the agency's mission of advocating for and supporting veterans and their representative organizations.
The Governor oversees the executive branch, including the administration of state laws regarding alcoholic beverages, and is responsible for the final approval and signing of the legislation.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes privacy protections for images and data captured by automated traffic enforcement systems, such as speed, red-light, and school bus cameras. It restricts the use of this data to traffic enforcement purposes unless a warrant or specific law enforcement documentation is provided, requires the immediate destruction of images that do not show a violation, and sets strict retention limits for evidence. Furthermore, the bill prohibits the use of biometric or facial recognition technology in these programs and prevents the sale or unauthorized sharing of recorded data.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland State Police, State Highway Administration, and local police departments or agencies implementing automated enforcement programs
qa_results.stakeholders: State and local law enforcement agencies, motorists, and third-party contractors involved in automated traffic enforcement.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill creates a potential fiscal impact on State and local law enforcement agencies due to additional administrative costs for managing data destruction, audit processes, and secure storage requirements. An agency that knowingly violates the privacy requirements is subject to a fine not exceeding $1,000 for each violation. The Judiciary and District Court are expected to manage any increase in warrant or subpoena requests with existing resources.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill requires the Chief Judge of the District Court to adopt procedures for issuing citations and managing civil penalties. Additionally, the fiscal note indicates the Judiciary will handle an increase in requests for warrants, subpoenas, and court orders required for accessing recorded images.

The fiscal note identifies potential administrative costs for state agencies to implement the required audit processes and data destruction protocols. As the principal fiscal and personnel agency, DBM oversees budget execution and personnel policies related to these impacts.
The bill specifically regulates school bus monitoring cameras, which are a key component of the automated enforcement programs under the oversight of local school systems and MSDE's coordination.

As the parent agency for the State Highway Administration and the Motor Vehicle Administration, MDOT is responsible for the broader transportation policies and infrastructure that utilize many of the automated enforcement systems regulated by this bill.
The Governor's Office oversees the executive branch agencies (including SHA and MSP) tasked with implementing these new privacy protections and audit procedures.

The Maryland State Police is explicitly defined as an 'agency' in the bill that implements and operates automated enforcement programs. It will be directly responsible for complying with the new privacy, warrant, and data destruction requirements.
The MVA manages vehicle titling, registration, and highway safety initiatives. It works closely with automated enforcement data to identify vehicle owners for citation issuance.

The bill mandates that agencies establish internal audit processes to ensure information is used only for authorized purposes. OLA is responsible for fiscal and compliance audits and may review these agency procedures.
The OAG provides legal counsel to state agencies on compliance with the Public Information Act and the new warrant and privacy requirements established by the bill.

The SHA is explicitly named as an 'agency' in the bill that operates automated enforcement programs (such as work zone speed control). It is a primary implementing agency for the bill's privacy and data management standards.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes the Workgroup on the Reorganization of the Maryland Transit Administration (MTA) to study and make recommendations on restructuring the Maryland Department of Transportation and the MTA. The workgroup is tasked with evaluating options to separate the management of local Baltimore City transit services (such as buses, light rail, and subway) from statewide transit services (such as MARC rail and the Purple Line), while ensuring Baltimore City maintains appropriate input and funding for its local transit services.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Transportation and Department of Legislative Services
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland transit commuters, Baltimore City residents, the Maryland Transit Administration, and the Maryland Department of Transportation.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: According to the Fiscal Note, State Transportation Trust Fund expenditures increase by an estimated $324,000 in both fiscal 2026 and 2027 (totaling $648,000) to hire expert consultants for legal, budgetary, and federal compliance analyses. The bill also expresses the General Assembly's intent for a $150,000 appropriation in the fiscal year 2027 budget for these consulting services.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill establishes a workgroup to study the reorganization of the Maryland Department of Transportation (MDOT) and the Maryland Transit Administration (MTA). The Secretary of Transportation serves on the workgroup, designates the chair, and the department is responsible for providing staff and submitting draft legislation based on the workgroup's findings.

The bill specifically mandates a study on the reorganization of the MTA. The Maryland Transit Administrator is a member of the workgroup, and the findings will directly impact the administration's structure, governance, and provision of transit services.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill creates a new temporary body, the Workgroup on the Reorganization of the Maryland Transit Administration, which falls under this collective category for specialized government studies and recommendations.
The Governor is responsible for appointing members to the workgroup and will receive the final report containing findings and recommendations for state agency reorganization.

As the principal fiscal and personnel agency, DBM is relevant because the proposed reorganization of MDOT and MTA will involve significant shifts in personnel and the allocation of funds within the Transportation Trust Fund. DBM was also a source of information for the fiscal note.

The OAG provides legal counsel to MDOT and MTA. The reorganization study specifically requires an analysis of current contractual obligations and the legal steps necessary to transfer those agreements.

GOPI oversees the efficiency and responsiveness of state government operations. A study aimed at reorganizing a major state administration like the MTA to improve service delivery and oversight aligns with GOPI's mission.
The Administrative Office of the Courts is identified as an information source for the fiscal note, indicating a minor role in providing data relevant to the bill's analysis.
The Treasurer's Office is identified as an information source for the fiscal note, providing financial data relevant to the study of MDOT/MTA finances and potential reorganization costs.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland Transit Administration (MTA) to provide one month of free ridership on the Purple Line light rail to residents living within a quarter-mile of the track upon the start of service. It also mandates that the MTA provide free promotional materials and services to small businesses located within a quarter-mile of the track beginning October 1, 2025, and continuing until three months after service commences.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Transit Administration
qa_results.stakeholders: Residents and small businesses located within a 0.25-mile radius of the Purple Line track.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State Transportation Trust Fund (TTF) revenues are projected to decrease by $75,000 in fiscal 2028 due to foregone fare revenue during the first month of Purple Line operations. TTF expenditures are expected to increase from fiscal 2026 through 2028 for the MTA to provide promotional materials and services to eligible small businesses, though the exact expenditure increase will depend on the program's final implementation regulations and is currently indeterminate.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill has a fiscal impact on the Transportation Trust Fund, which the Department of Budget and Management monitors as the state's principal fiscal agency responsible for budget execution and revenue estimation.
The bill mandates a promotional program for small businesses, aligning with the Department of Commerce's mission to support existing companies and enhance the state's competitive economic position.

As the parent agency of the Maryland Transit Administration (MTA), MDOT oversees the Transportation Trust Fund, which will see a decrease in revenues and an increase in expenditures due to the implementation of the free ridership and promotional programs.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Small, Minority & Women Business Affairs
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill specifically targets small businesses for promotional assistance; this office coordinates small business programs and monitors socioeconomic policies across state agencies.

The Maryland Transit Administration is the primary agency tasked with developing and implementing the free ridership program for the Purple Line, providing promotional materials to small businesses, and adopting necessary regulations.
The Office of the Attorney General will likely provide legal counsel and review the regulations that the Maryland Transit Administration is required to adopt under this bill.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill authorizes police officers in Baltimore County to enforce the Maryland Vehicle Law on private roadways within the Queen Anne Village community in Owings Mills from October 1, 2025, through July 1, 2028. It specifically prohibits driving in violation of these laws on those private roads and requires the Baltimore County Police Department to report on the bill's implementation and impact by September 1, 2028.
qa_results.responsible_party: Baltimore County Police Department
qa_results.stakeholders: Residents and drivers in the Queen Anne Village community in Owings Mills, Baltimore County
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is not anticipated to materially affect State finances. Baltimore County is expected to handle enforcement within the Queen Anne Village community using existing resources, and the Fiscal Note indicates that revenues are not affected.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill amends the Transportation Article of the Maryland Code, which is overseen by the Maryland Department of Transportation and its Motor Vehicle Administration. These agencies are the primary custodians of the vehicle laws being extended to private roadways in the specified community.

As the primary state agency for traffic safety and vehicle law enforcement, the Maryland State Police is relevant to legislation expanding enforcement authority and was consulted as a technical information source for the bill's development.

The authorization of police to enforce traffic laws on additional roadways will result in the issuance of citations, which must be processed and adjudicated through the state's judicial system supported by this agency.

The Office of the Attorney General provides essential legal counsel regarding the statutory interpretation of the Maryland Vehicle Law and the legal authority of the state to permit enforcement on private property.

The Governor's Office oversees the executive branch and handles the approval of legislation related to public safety, law enforcement policy, and intergovernmental relations with local jurisdictions like Baltimore County.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill authorizes Maryland judges to consider the existence of a military protection order (MPO) when determining whether to grant a temporary peace or protective order against a respondent. Additionally, it requires law enforcement officers who have probable cause to believe a service member has violated a state-issued order to notify the law enforcement agency that issued the MPO if that MPO is entered in the FBI's National Crime Information Center database.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Judiciary (Administrative Office of the Courts) and Maryland Law Enforcement Agencies
qa_results.stakeholders: Service members of the U.S. uniformed services and National Guard, judges, law enforcement officers, and petitioners seeking peace or protective orders.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: According to the Fiscal Note, state general fund expenditures for the Judiciary increase by $99,900 in fiscal 2026 for one-time programming costs. There is no estimated impact on state revenues or local government operations.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly impacts the Maryland Judicial Branch by authorizing judges to consider military protection orders during peace and protective order hearings. The fiscal note explicitly identifies $99,900 in general fund expenditures for the Judiciary for one-time programming costs to implement the required changes to court systems and procedures.

As the primary statewide law enforcement agency, the Maryland State Police is responsible for the bill's new requirement that law enforcement officers check the NCIC database for military protection orders (MPOs) and notify the issuing agency if a service member is found to be in violation.

The Adjutant General heads the Maryland Military Department and oversees the Maryland National Guard. The bill specifically recognizes protection orders issued by commanding officers within the Maryland National Guard and establishes a notification protocol where civilian law enforcement must contact military authorities regarding violations.

The bill defines 'Military Protection Order' to include those issued by commanding officers in the Maryland National Guard. It integrates these military-issued orders into the civilian court process for determining the necessity of peace and protective orders.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill references the Executive Director of the Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy within the statutory definitions of the Family Law Article being amended. Additionally, this office coordinates public safety strategies and funding that may be impacted by changes to protective order protocols.

The Department of Human Services, through its local departments of social services, frequently serves as a petitioner for protective orders on behalf of children and vulnerable adults. The bill's change to the criteria for determining abuse (considering MPOs) directly affects the evidence and arguments used by the department in these proceedings.

This agency provides advocacy and support for Maryland's service members and their families. The bill affects the legal status and civilian court treatment of active-duty members and their families who are subject to or protected by military-issued orders.

The Office of the Attorney General provides legal counsel to state agencies, including law enforcement and the courts, on the implementation and legal interpretation of new statutes regarding peace and protective orders.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes the Abandoned and Neglected Cemeteries Fund to provide for the care, preservation, maintenance, and restoration of abandoned and neglected cemeteries in Maryland. It defines relevant cemetery conditions, authorizes the Governor to include a discretionary $250,000 appropriation in the annual budget bill for the fund, and requires the Secretary of Labor to submit an annual report on the administration and usage of the fund.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Labor
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland Department of Labor, local governments, and Maryland residents residing near or associated with abandoned or neglected cemeteries.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: According to the Fiscal Note, state general fund expenditures increase by $250,000 annually beginning in fiscal 2026, assuming the Governor exercises the authority to provide the discretionary appropriation. Special fund revenues and expenditures for the Maryland Department of Labor increase by an equivalent amount to support the care and restoration of cemeteries. The department is expected to administer the fund with existing resources. There is no fiscal impact on local governments.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill authorizes the Governor to include a discretionary appropriation of $250,000 in the annual budget bill for the Abandoned and Neglected Cemeteries Fund.
The Comptroller is responsible for accounting for the new special fund, ensuring proper fiscal tracking of its revenues and expenditures.
The Treasurer is mandated to hold the fund separately and invest the money, ensuring that interest earnings are credited to the fund.
The OAG provides legal counsel to the Department of Labor regarding the administration, regulatory oversight, and legal implications of the new cemetery fund.
DBM is responsible for the fiscal management and implementation of the $250,000 appropriation and the oversight of the new non-lapsing special fund.
The Secretary of Labor is the primary administrator of the Abandoned and Neglected Cemeteries Fund, responsible for its implementation, use of funds, and annual reporting to the General Assembly.

As the agency overseeing historical and cultural programs through the Maryland Historical Trust, the department may provide expertise or coordinate on the preservation and restoration of historical cemeteries.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill transfers the administration and coordination of the federal Commodity Supplemental Food Program from the Maryland Department of Aging to the Family Investment Administration within the Department of Human Services.
qa_results.responsible_party: Department of Human Services, Family Investment Administration
qa_results.stakeholders: Low-income individuals aged 60 and older, the Maryland Department of Human Services, and the Maryland Department of Aging.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill redirects approximately $300,000 in annual federal funding from the Maryland Department of Aging (MDOA) to the Department of Human Services (DHS). In fiscal 2026, MDOA federal fund revenues and expenditures decrease by $225,000, with DHS seeing a corresponding increase. Additionally, MDOA general fund expenditures increase by $22,000 in fiscal 2026 and approximately $29,000 annually thereafter to cover personnel costs previously funded by federal administrative dollars.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill repeals the requirement for the Secretary of Aging to administer the federal Commodity Supplemental Food Program (CSFP), transferring these responsibilities and associated federal funding to the Department of Human Services. This results in a notable fiscal impact, including a decrease in federal fund revenues and an increase in general fund expenditures to maintain personnel costs previously covered by the program.

The bill designates the Family Investment Administration within the Department of Human Services as the central coordinating and directing agency for the federal Commodity Supplemental Food Program. The agency will assume administration of the program and receive the associated federal funds formerly managed by the Department of Aging.

As the agency responsible for budget development and execution, the Department of Budget and Management will oversee the transfer of federal fund appropriations between agencies and the necessary increase in general fund expenditures required to support staffing at the Department of Aging following the transfer.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill creates a nonprofit organizations navigator position within the Maryland Department of Commerce to help nonprofits access and apply for state grants, resolve procedural delays, and share information on funding opportunities. The navigator also serves as a member of the Maryland Efficient Grant Application Council. The bill repeals a previous requirement to study a state grants ombudsperson and terminates in 2027.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Commerce
qa_results.stakeholders: Nonprofit organizations in Maryland
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund expenditures increase by $80,400 in FY 2026 and $69,800 in FY 2027 to hire a contractual navigator. The FY 2026 budget passed by the General Assembly includes the $80,400 for this position. There is no estimated impact on state revenues or local government finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill establishes the Nonprofit Organizations Navigator within the Department of Commerce. The Secretary of Commerce is responsible for designating the Navigator and the department must report on the position's impact by January 2027.

The Secretary of Budget and Management chairs the Maryland Efficient Grant Application (MEGA) Council, of which the new Navigator will be a member. DBM is also responsible for adopting regulations and providing technical assistance for the grants management system the Navigator supports.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill explicitly alters the composition and duties of the Maryland Efficient Grant Application Council, which falls under this category of advisory bodies.

The Navigator's duties include collecting and sharing information on federal, state, and local grants and providing technical assistance to nonprofits, which overlaps with the mission of the Governor's Grants Office to manage federal grant information and resources.
The Chief Procurement Officer, who is part of DGS, is a statutory member of the MEGA Council, which the Navigator joins to address grant-making procedural complexities.
The State Treasurer is a statutory member of the MEGA Council and the agency shares staffing responsibilities for the council.
The Comptroller is a statutory member of the MEGA Council and the agency shares staffing responsibilities for the council.
The Attorney General is a statutory member of the MEGA Council and the agency shares staffing responsibilities for the council.
The Secretary of Health is a statutory member of the MEGA Council and the agency shares staffing responsibilities for the council.
The Secretary of Human Services is a statutory member of the MEGA Council and the agency shares staffing responsibilities for the council.
The Secretary of Housing and Community Development is a statutory member of the MEGA Council and the agency shares staffing responsibilities for the council.
The Secretary of Agriculture is a statutory member of the MEGA Council and the agency shares staffing responsibilities for the council.
The Secretary of the Environment is a statutory member of the MEGA Council and the agency shares staffing responsibilities for the council.
The State Superintendent of Schools is a statutory member of the MEGA Council and the agency shares staffing responsibilities for the council.
The Director of the MEA is a statutory member of the MEGA Council and the agency shares staffing responsibilities for the council.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Executive Director of GOCPP is a statutory member of the MEGA Council and the agency shares staffing responsibilities for the council.
The Chair of the Commission is a statutory member of the MEGA Council and the agency shares staffing responsibilities for the council.
The Secretary of Natural Resources is a statutory member of the MEGA Council and the agency shares staffing responsibilities for the council.
The Governor appoints five representatives of private nonprofit organizations to the MEGA Council and coordinates policy initiatives across the executive branch agencies involved in this bill.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill authorizes local departments of social services to request assistance from federal law enforcement officers during investigations of vulnerable adult abuse, neglect, or exploitation. It also extends existing confidentiality protections and disclosure rules for human services programs to specifically include Adult Protective Services (APS), prohibiting unauthorized disclosure while allowing for specific legal and administrative exceptions.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Human Services
qa_results.stakeholders: Vulnerable adults, local departments of social services, and federal law enforcement officers.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: According to the Fiscal Note, the bill is not anticipated to materially affect State or local finances. State and local entities involved in investigations regarding vulnerable adults may experience operational efficiencies.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Department of Human Services is the primary agency responsible for the state's social services and oversees the local departments of social services that are tasked with conducting the adult protective services investigations modified by this bill.

The Secretary of Aging is explicitly named in the bill as a statutory advisor for the development and supervision of the protective services program, and the department is authorized to assist in investigations.

The Secretary of Health is explicitly required to provide advice on the development and implementation of the adult protective services program, and the bill relates to the disclosure of information concerning medical assistance.

The OAG provides legal counsel to the departments implementing these changes and oversees legal interpretations of state disclosure and confidentiality laws, as well as the intersection with law enforcement investigations.
The bill focuses on vulnerable adults and disabled individuals who lack the capacity to care for themselves, a core population served and coordinated for by the Department of Disabilities.

The bill involves the participation of fiduciary institutions in investigations of financial exploitation and allows for the disclosure of certain information to these institutions; the Department of Labor regulates the financial institutions mentioned.
As a primary law enforcement agency, the Maryland State Police may be requested to assist local departments in investigations of alleged abuse or exploitation of vulnerable adults.
The Governor's Office oversees the executive branch departments (DHS, MDH, Aging) implementing the bill and is responsible for the overall state policy regarding the protection of vulnerable adults.
The bill contains a cross-reference to voter registration administration within the section regarding the disclosure of human services records.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes a formal appeals process for taxpayers subject to the digital advertising gross revenues tax who receive a notice of assessment from the Maryland Comptroller. It authorizes the Comptroller to issue orders to correct or abate erroneous assessments, aligning the administrative and appeals procedures for this tax with those of other state taxes.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Comptroller’s Office
qa_results.stakeholders: Digital advertising service providers with at least $100 million in global annual gross revenues that are subject to Maryland's digital advertising gross revenues tax.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: General fund expenditures increase by $132,100 in FY 2026 for the Comptroller’s Office to hire two senior tax attorneys to manage digital advertising tax appeals. These expenditures are projected to increase annually, reaching approximately $260,900 by FY 2030. State revenues are not directly affected, and there is no local fiscal impact.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Comptroller is the primary agency responsible for administering the digital advertising gross revenues tax. The bill explicitly tasks the Comptroller or their designee with conducting informal hearings, acting on applications for revision, and issuing orders to correct erroneous assessments.

The bill establishes an administrative appeal process for digital advertising taxes. The Maryland Tax Court is the higher authority that hears appeals from the final decisions made by the Comptroller, and the fiscal note indicates that many such cases are already being filed in this court.

The bill has a direct fiscal impact of over $132,000 in FY 2026 for the hiring of new senior tax attorneys. As the state's principal personnel and budget agency, DBM is responsible for overseeing the creation of these positions and the allocation of general funds.

The OAG provides legal counsel and representation to the Comptroller's Office. Given the fiscal note's mention of 'constitutional issues' and 'legal determinations' related to the digital advertising tax, the OAG will be involved in advising the agency during the appeals process.

The Governor oversees the executive branch, including the Comptroller's Office, and is responsible for proposing the state budget that must account for the personnel expenditures required by this bill.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland Medical Assistance Program to provide coverage for self-measured blood pressure monitoring for eligible recipients who are pregnant, postpartum, or have been diagnosed with chronic kidney disease, diabetes, heart disease, or a cardiometabolic disease. The coverage must include the provision of validated home blood pressure monitors and reimbursement for healthcare provider time related to training, data transmission, and monitoring.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health
qa_results.stakeholders: Pregnant and postpartum Medicaid recipients, Medicaid recipients with specific chronic conditions (diabetes, heart disease, kidney disease, or cardiometabolic disease), and healthcare providers.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: According to the Fiscal Note, there is no meaningful fiscal impact on the state because the Maryland Medical Assistance Program currently covers self-measured blood pressure monitoring, equipment, and related provider services for participants based on medical necessity. Local health departments may receive reimbursements for services specified under the bill, but expenditures are not expected to be affected.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland Department of Health (MDH) is the primary agency responsible for administering the Maryland Medical Assistance Program (Medicaid). The bill directly mandates MDH to provide coverage for self-measured blood pressure monitoring for specific eligible recipients and requires the department to submit an annual report on outcomes and cost savings to the General Assembly.

The Governor's Office oversees the executive branch, including the Department of Health, and is responsible for policy coordination and the annual state budget, which must accommodate the mandated Medicaid coverage provided for in the bill.

The bill specifies that the mandated coverage is subject to the limitations of the State budget. As the principal fiscal agency, DBM supervises budget execution and fiscal planning for the Medicaid program.

The bill's focus on maternal health and postpartum care aligns with the Governor's Office for Children's mission to improve well-being for families and ensure access to health services for historically underinvested communities.

As an independent regulatory agency within the Department of Health, the MHCC is responsible for planning for the state's health system needs and improving access to health care, which includes monitoring the effectiveness of health services like blood pressure monitoring.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill allows specific food establishments, including agritourism businesses, Class 4 limited wineries, and Class 8 farm breweries, to meet the legal requirement of providing a convenient lavatory by providing a portable chemical toilet. These toilets must be sanitary, properly ventilated, supplied with soap and hand-drying methods, and located at least 25 feet from any well.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health
qa_results.stakeholders: Agritourism businesses, Class 4 limited wineries, Class 8 farm breweries, and members of the public visiting these establishments.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The Maryland Department of Health can update regulations and provide guidance to local health departments using existing budgeted resources. Local health departments can manage inspections and complaint responses within existing resources. State and local revenues are not affected. Small businesses may see reduced startup costs by using portable chemical toilets instead of constructing permanent lavatory facilities.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the primary agency for food health and safety, MDH is responsible for food establishment regulations (COMAR 10.15.03) and must update them to allow chemical toilets for specified businesses. The agency also provides guidance to the local health departments that conduct these inspections.

The bill requires portable chemical toilets to be placed at least 25 feet from a well to protect water quality, which falls under MDE's environmental protection mission. MDE also oversees current state regulations regarding the construction and venting of chemical toilets.

The bill specifically applies to agritourism businesses and farm-based wineries and breweries. MDA provides leadership and support to these agricultural communities and promotes the economic viability of farming operations.

The Comptroller's office is responsible for regulating the alcohol industry. The bill specifically affects Class 4 limited wineries and Class 8 farm breweries licensed under the Alcoholic Beverages and Cannabis Article.

The bill references agritourism as defined in the Land Use Article. The Department of Planning provides policy guidance and data analysis regarding land use and sustainable growth for these types of businesses.

The council supports the economic development and quality of life in Maryland's rural counties, specifically through the support of agriculture and regional cooperation for farm-based businesses impacted by this legislation.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland Agricultural & Resource-Based Industry Development Corp.
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: MARBIDCO is tasked with supporting the profitability of Maryland's agricultural and forestry industries. This bill has a potential meaningful small business effect by reducing the infrastructure costs for new farm-based wineries, breweries, and agritourism entities.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill reduces the number of members elected to the Baltimore County Republican Party Central Committee from four to three for each councilmanic district and reorganizes the membership of the Baltimore County Democratic Party Central Committee across various legislative districts within the county.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland State Board of Elections, Baltimore County Republican Party Central Committee, and Baltimore County Democratic Party Central Committee
qa_results.stakeholders: Members and candidates of political party central committees in Baltimore County and registered voters belonging to the Republican and Democratic parties in the county.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: According to the fiscal note, the bill does not directly affect Maryland State or Baltimore County finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland State Board of Elections is responsible for supervising and administering elections in the state. Since political party central committee members are elected during primary elections, the board must ensure that ballot configurations for Baltimore County reflect the altered number of seats and legislative district alignments mandated by this bill.

The Office of the Attorney General provides legal counsel to the State Board of Elections and is responsible for interpreting the Election Law Article of the Maryland Code. They may be required to provide guidance on the implementation of these structural changes to local party governance.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes a venue beer, wine, and liquor license in Dorchester County for nonprofit or for-profit businesses that host events like weddings and banquets. To qualify, a venue must be at least 2,000 square feet and accommodate at least 100 individuals. The license allows for the on-premises sale and consumption of alcohol during events where food is provided.
qa_results.responsible_party: Board of License Commissioners for Dorchester County
qa_results.stakeholders: Nonprofit and for-profit retail businesses hosting events in Dorchester County, event attendees, and the Dorchester County Board of License Commissioners.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: Dorchester County revenues will increase starting in fiscal 2026 due to the collection of a $1,500 annual license fee for each venue license issued. The total revenue increase depends on the number of licenses granted. There is no impact on State finances, and the county can handle additional enforcement activities with existing resources.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Comptroller of Maryland is the primary state agency responsible for regulating the alcohol industry according to the provided summary. This bill establishes a new alcoholic beverages license category ('venue beer, wine, and liquor license') in Dorchester County. While the license is issued by a local board, the bill directly concerns the regulation of the alcohol industry, which falls under the Comptroller's oversight duties. Additionally, the Comptroller is responsible for collecting state sales taxes, which apply to the on-premises alcohol sales authorized by this bill.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires the State Board of Pharmacy to send renewal notices for licenses, permits, and registrations via email instead of first-class mail, unless the recipient specifically requests to receive the notice by mail.
qa_results.responsible_party: State Board of Pharmacy
qa_results.stakeholders: Licensed pharmacists, pharmacy permit holders, registered pharmacy technicians, wholesale distributor permit holders, and registered pharmacy interns.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State special fund expenditures are estimated to decrease by approximately $14,500 annually starting in fiscal 2026 due to reduced printing and postage costs. There is no impact on State revenues or local government finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The State Board of Pharmacy is an entity within the Maryland Department of Health. The bill directly impacts the Department's operations by mandating that its Board shift from paper-based to electronic renewal notices for pharmacists, pharmacies, technicians, and interns, which is central to the Department's role in regulating healthcare professionals.

The bill has a direct fiscal impact on the state's budget, reducing special fund expenditures by an estimated $14,500 annually due to decreased mailing and printing costs. DBM is responsible for supervising budget execution and fiscal planning related to these changes.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill alters the licensing fees for various alcoholic beverages licenses in Dorchester County. It increases fees for most license classes, decreases the fee for Class C beer licenses, and authorizes the Board of License Commissioners for Dorchester County to charge new application fees ($150 or $200) for new licenses and a $50 transfer fee.
qa_results.responsible_party: Board of License Commissioners for Dorchester County
qa_results.stakeholders: Small business restaurants, bars, and other alcoholic beverages license holders in Dorchester County.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: According to the fiscal note, Dorchester County license fee revenues will increase by at least 10,250 dollars annually beginning in fiscal 2026. This estimate is based on the 66 businesses currently holding licenses that will see fee increases under the bill. There is no impact on state revenues or expenditures. Small businesses will experience a potential meaningful financial impact due to the increased license and application fees.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This bill directly affects the Board of License Commissioners for Dorchester County, which is an ongoing regulatory body authorized by the General Assembly. The board is responsible for implementing the new licensing, application, and transfer fees established by the bill.

The Comptroller is the primary state official responsible for regulating the alcohol industry and enforcing state tax laws related to it. Since this bill alters licensing fees within the Alcoholic Beverages and Cannabis Article, it relates to the Comptroller's oversight of the industry.

The Office of the Attorney General provides legal counsel to state agencies, boards, and commissions, which includes local boards of license commissioners established under state law. They may be called upon to provide legal guidance regarding the implementation of these fee changes.
As the head of the executive branch, the Governor oversees all state-authorized regulatory boards and signed this bill into law.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes an arts beer and wine license in Dorchester County, which may be issued to nonprofit or for-profit art-related retail businesses, such as art galleries, museums, or art centers, located within a state-approved arts and entertainment district. License holders are permitted to sell beer and wine for on-premises consumption between 10:00 a.m. and 10:00 p.m. daily, provided that snacks are also served. The bill also allows the Dorchester County Board of License Commissioners to issue the license to establishments within 300 feet of a school or place of worship if written consent is obtained from those institutions.
qa_results.responsible_party: Board of License Commissioners for Dorchester County
qa_results.stakeholders: Nonprofit and for-profit retail art businesses, art galleries, museums, and art centers located in Dorchester County's arts and entertainment districts, as well as the Dorchester County Board of License Commissioners.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no impact on state finances. Locally, Dorchester County revenues will increase starting in fiscal 2026 to the extent that $250 annual arts beer and wine licenses are issued. Total aggregate revenue estimates are unavailable as they depend on the number of license applications. The county is expected to manage enforcement activities using existing resources.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill stipulates that a business must be located in an arts and entertainment district approved by the Department of Commerce to be eligible for the newly established arts beer and wine license.
The Comptroller serves as the state's principal regulator of the alcoholic beverage industry and is responsible for enforcing related tax laws and auditing taxpayers within this sector.
The Governor's Office oversees the executive branch departments involved in district approval and signed the legislation into law.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill renames the existing beer and wine tasting license in Dorchester County to the beer, wine, and liquor tasting (BWLT) license. It authorizes Class A license holders to conduct liquor tastings in addition to beer and wine, provided they are authorized to sell liquor under their Class A license, and establishes maximum quantity limits for liquor consumption during these tastings.
qa_results.responsible_party: Dorchester County Board of License Commissioners
qa_results.stakeholders: Class A alcoholic beverages license holders and consumers in Dorchester County
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no State fiscal impact. According to the Fiscal Note, Dorchester County revenues are not affected because the license fees ($150 for up to 15 tastings per year or $250 for up to 30 tastings per year) remain unchanged from the previous beer and wine tasting license. Any additional enforcement activity by the county can be handled with existing resources.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Comptroller of Maryland is responsible for regulating the alcohol industry and collecting state revenues related to it. As this bill modifies regulations concerning alcoholic beverage licenses (specifically liquor tasting in Dorchester County) within the Alcoholic Beverages and Cannabis Article, it falls under the Comptroller's general regulatory oversight of the industry.
The Governor's Office is the executive entity that oversees the enforcement of state laws and signed this specific legislation into law as Chapter 828.

The Office of the Attorney General serves as the chief legal representative for the state and provides counsel to state agencies regarding the interpretation and implementation of the Alcoholic Beverages and Cannabis Article of the Maryland Code.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill authorizes Class C license holders (including clubs, fraternal/sororal organizations, and veterans' organizations) in Anne Arundel County to sell alcoholic beverages for on-premises consumption during events to members and guests. It establishes a new $100 annual event permit for veterans' organizations that allows sales to non-members during events. Additionally, the bill requires outside groups hosting events at these licensed premises to obtain their own per diem licenses from the local board.
qa_results.responsible_party: Anne Arundel County Board of License Commissioners
qa_results.stakeholders: Class C alcoholic beverages license holders in Anne Arundel County (clubs, fraternal/sororal organizations, and veterans' organizations) and outside groups hosting events at these facilities.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: There is no State fiscal impact. Local revenues in Anne Arundel County are expected to increase due to the collection of a new $100 annual event permit fee for veterans' organizations and additional per diem license fees ($25 or $50) for outside groups hosting events at Class C premises. Specific total dollar estimates are unavailable as they depend on the volume of permits issued.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the head of the executive branch, the Governor's Office is responsible for overseeing the implementation of state laws and signing or vetoing legislation, including changes to the Alcoholic Beverages and Cannabis Article.

The Comptroller's Office is explicitly identified in its summary as the agency that regulates the alcohol, tobacco, and motor fuel industries in Maryland, making this bill's changes to alcoholic beverages licensing directly relevant to its regulatory scope.

The OAG serves as the chief legal officer for the state and provides counsel to the General Assembly and state agencies on the interpretation and enforcement of state laws, including the modified provisions of the Alcoholic Beverages and Cannabis Article.

This bill specifically modifies the privileges of Class C (veterans' organization) licenses and establishes an event permit for them, directly affecting the operations of veterans' groups which the DVMF is tasked with supporting and advocating for.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill expands the authorized courses of study for expanded function dental assistant (EFDA) certification to include programs from the DALE Foundation and Trapezio Orthodontic Assistant Training Solutions. It requires initial certification courses to consist of at least 35 hours of instruction involving both online and in-person components and establishes specific requirements for the State Board of Dental Examiners to reinstate expired EFDA certificates, including continuing education and fees.
qa_results.responsible_party: State Board of Dental Examiners
qa_results.stakeholders: Expanded function dental assistants, dental assistant certification applicants, the State Board of Dental Examiners, and State-based dental professional societies.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: According to the fiscal note, the bill's requirements can be absorbed within existing budgeted resources and state revenues are not affected. There is no local fiscal impact and the impact on small businesses is minimal.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The State Board of Dental Examiners is a regulatory board within the Department of Health. This bill directly mandates the Board to approve specific courses of study, adopt new regulations for instruction hours, and establish requirements for certificate reinstatement.
The Office of the Attorney General provides legal counsel to the State Board of Dental Examiners and will be responsible for reviewing the new regulations required by the bill for legal sufficiency.
The bill defines approved courses of study for dental assistants to include programs within institutions of postsecondary education, which are coordinated and regulated by this commission.
The bill identifies dental assisting programs located within high schools as approved courses of study; the Department of Education oversees the policies and standards for these schools.

As the head of the executive branch, the Governor's Office oversees the Department of Health and signed this bill into law; the Board of Dental Examiners functions under the Governor's executive authority.

As the state's principal fiscal agency, DBM oversees the budget execution for the Board and the Department of Health, ensuring the bill's requirements are absorbed within existing resources as noted in the fiscal note.
The bill references U.S. Department of Labor Job Corps programs as approved educational pathways, and the state agency manages related workforce development and adult learning initiatives.

The OAH adjudicates contested cases for the Board of Dental Examiners; any legal disputes regarding the newly established reinstatement procedures or certificate denials would be heard by this agency.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill authorizes the St. Mary’s County Board of License Commissioners to issue up to three Class B beer, wine, and liquor restaurant licenses to a single individual or entity for use at separate premises. It restricts off-premises sales privileges to only one of these licenses and prohibits individuals from holding a direct or indirect interest in more than three such licenses.
qa_results.responsible_party: Board of License Commissioners for St. Mary’s County
qa_results.stakeholders: Restaurant owners and alcoholic beverages license applicants in St. Mary’s County
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: According to the fiscal note, the bill has no state impact and is not expected to materially affect St. Mary's County operations or finances. The current annual fee for the Class B beer, wine, and liquor restaurant license is $650.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the state's chief regulator of the alcohol industry, the Comptroller's office oversees the broader regulatory and tax collection environment in which local liquor licensing boards operate.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The St. Mary’s County Board of License Commissioners, which is the primary body authorized by this bill to issue additional licenses and enforce the new interest restrictions, is a permanent regulatory body appointed by the Governor.
The Governor's Office oversees the executive branch, approves legislation, and holds the authority to appoint members to the local boards of license commissioners.
The Office of Appointments is responsible for vetting and recommending candidates for the St. Mary's County Board of License Commissioners, which is empowered by this bill.

The OAG provides legal counsel to state and local boards and would be responsible for advising on the legal interpretation of the bill's new definitions regarding 'indirect interest' and licensing limits.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill reduces the frequency of reports that the Maryland Attorney General must submit to the General Assembly regarding the recovery of economic damages from the Francis Scott Key Bridge collapse and the resulting Port of Baltimore closure. The reporting requirement is changed from once a month to once every six months.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Office of the Attorney General
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland General Assembly, the Office of the Attorney General, and the public following the recovery efforts for economic damages related to the Port of Baltimore and Francis Scott Key Bridge.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The Fiscal Note indicates that the bill has no state or local fiscal impact, as the reduction in reporting frequency does not affect state finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Office of the Attorney General is the primary agency responsible for pursuing the litigation to recover economic damages and for submitting the status reports to the General Assembly as required by the PORT Act. This bill directly alters the frequency of their statutory reporting obligation.

As the parent agency for the state's transportation network, MDOT oversees the modal administrations (MPA and MDTA) whose assets and operations were directly impacted by the Port closure and Bridge collapse, which are the subjects of the Attorney General's recovery reports.

The Maryland Port Administration operates the Helen Delich Bentley Port of Baltimore; the Attorney General's reports specifically track the recovery of economic damages related to the closure and restoration of this facility.

The Maryland Transportation Authority is responsible for the Francis Scott Key Bridge. The Attorney General's reports concern the recovery of economic damages for the collapse of this specific toll facility managed by MDTA.

The State Treasurer acts as the custodian of state funds and property and manages the State Insurance Trust Fund. The reports from the Attorney General involve the status of recovering funds and property-related damages for the state.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires the Comptroller of Maryland to study the process by which its Field Enforcement Bureau enforces miscellaneous State business licenses. The study, conducted in consultation with specific industry and legal stakeholders, must examine the potential use of civil citations, methods for identifying responsible business owners, and enforcement procedures for out-of-state owners, with a report due to the General Assembly by December 1, 2025.
qa_results.responsible_party: Comptroller of Maryland
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland business owners, operators, the Alcohol, Tobacco, and Cannabis Commission, the Maryland Chamber of Commerce, the Maryland Retailers Alliance, the Maryland Restaurant Association, the Job Opportunities Task Force, and the Maryland Circuit Court Clerks’ Association.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: According to the Fiscal Note, the Comptroller’s Office can conduct the study and prepare the required report with existing resources. There is no impact on state or local revenues or expenditures.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill mandates the Comptroller to lead the study of the Field Enforcement Bureau's enforcement of miscellaneous State business licenses and submit a report to the General Assembly.

The study must consult the Maryland Circuit Court Clerks' Association; these clerks are responsible for issuing the miscellaneous business licenses under Title 17, and changes to the citation process would impact the judiciary.

The bill explicitly requires the Comptroller to consult with the Alcohol, Tobacco, and Cannabis Commission, of which the Maryland Cannabis Administration is the primary state entity for cannabis regulation.
The Department of Labor was identified as a source of information for the fiscal note and oversees various business regulations and workforce requirements related to state commerce.
The OAG provides legal counsel to the Comptroller and would likely be involved in reviewing the legal implications of shifting from criminal to civil citations for business license violations.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill updates the Maryland Annotated Code by replacing obsolete and gendered terminology related to the Maryland State Firefighters Association (formerly the Maryland State Firemen's Association) and its members. It replaces terms like 'fireman,' 'firemen,' and 'squadman' with 'firefighter,' 'firefighters,' and 'squad member' or 'squad person' to reflect the association's recent name change and modernize legal references.
qa_results.responsible_party: The publisher of the Annotated Code of Maryland, in consultation with the Department of Legislative Services.
qa_results.stakeholders: Members of the Maryland State Firefighters Association, volunteer firefighters, volunteer ambulance and rescue squad members, and Maryland state and local government agencies.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no state or local fiscal impact as the changes are technical in nature and do not affect governmental finances, according to the Fiscal Note.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill updates the name of the association that must submit annual reports to the Comptroller regarding members qualifying for income tax subtraction modifications. It also updates terminology relevant to the Comptroller's Field Enforcement Bureau in regards to contagious disease exposure protocols.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill updates the name of the association that provides tax qualification reports to the department. It also amends the terminology used for the department's Intelligence and Investigative Division regarding protocols for notifying personnel of exposure to contagious diseases.

The bill explicitly requires the Administration to consult with the Maryland State Firefighters Association (under its updated name) when adopting regulations related to driver's licenses for volunteer firefighters.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland Institute for Emergency Medical Services Systems
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill updates the name of the representative association on the Emergency Medical Services Advisory Council, which is part of the state's emergency medical services network overseen by MIEMSS.

The bill updates terminology related to scholarships for children of volunteer firefighters and rescue squad members, and covers campus police forces under the commission's jurisdiction regarding contagious disease exposure notifications.

The bill updates the name of the association receiving funds from court costs distributed to the Widows' and Orphans' Fund, a process managed through the state budget and the judicial branch's financial operations.
The bill updates terminology within minor employment laws enforced by the department, specifically regarding minors working as firefighters on commercial vessels.
The bill updates definitions and terminology for disease exposure notification protocols that apply to medical care facilities and emergency responders regulated by the department.

The bill updates terminology in laws specifically governing the notification and safety protocols for law enforcement officers, including those in the Department of State Police, regarding exposure to contagious diseases.
The bill amends provisions in the Transportation Article regarding emergency vehicle lighting and driver regulations, affecting modal administrations such as MDOT SHA and the MVA.
The bill updates terminology regarding contagious disease exposure and training requirements for the MTA police force.
The bill updates terminology regarding contagious disease exposure and training requirements for the MDTA police force.
The bill updates terminology regarding contagious disease exposure and training requirements for the Port Administration police force.
The bill updates terminology regarding contagious disease exposure and training requirements for law enforcement officers of the Department of Natural Resources.
The bill updates terminology regarding contagious disease exposure and training requirements for campus police forces of constituent institutions of the University System of Maryland.
The bill updates terminology regarding contagious disease exposure and training requirements for Morgan State University's police force.
The bill updates terminology regarding contagious disease exposure and training requirements for the college's police force.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires the State Retirement Agency to convene a workgroup consisting of various stakeholders to study the requirements and processes for transferring member service between State and local retirement and pension systems and to recommend improvements and legislative changes.
qa_results.responsible_party: State Retirement Agency
qa_results.stakeholders: State and local retirement system members, the State Retirement Agency, the Department of Legislative Services, the American Federation of State, County, and Municipal Employees (AFSCME), and representatives from Baltimore City, Baltimore County, Howard County, Anne Arundel County, and Frederick County retirement plans.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: According to the fiscal note, there is no state or local fiscal impact. The State Retirement Agency is expected to convene and staff the workgroup using existing budgeted resources.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill explicitly requires the State Retirement Agency to convene, staff, and provide a report for the workgroup studying member service transfers between retirement systems. It is the primary implementing agency.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This bill creates a temporary workgroup composed of appointed officials and stakeholders to conduct a specific study and provide recommendations, which falls under the definition of this collective entity.
The workgroup is required to submit its final report and legislative recommendations to the Governor.
