qa_results.bill_summary: This bill authorizes the Maryland Stadium Authority, Morgan State University, St. Mary’s College of Maryland, and Baltimore City Community College to establish a procurement preference program for bidders and offerors that utilize employee stock ownership plans (ESOPs). For contracts valued at less than $80,000,000, these units may include an evaluation factor or price preference of up to 10% for ESOP-utilizing entities during the evaluation of bids or proposals. The bill also requires contractors to provide written verification of their ESOP status and mandates a report on the program's effectiveness by December 1, 2028.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Stadium Authority, Morgan State University, St. Mary’s College of Maryland, and Baltimore City Community College
qa_results.stakeholders: Contractors and businesses that utilize Employee Stock Ownership Plans (ESOPs), competing non-ESOP businesses, the Maryland Stadium Authority, and Maryland public higher education institutions (excluding the University System of Maryland from the preference application but including it in reporting requirements).
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State expenditures (including general, higher education, and nonbudgeted funds) may increase by up to 10% for each procurement contract where the evaluation factor is applied by the Maryland Stadium Authority, Morgan State University, St. Mary’s College of Maryland, or Baltimore City Community College. Because the program is optional and the number and value of future contracts cannot be determined in advance, a specific total dollar estimate is unavailable.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill explicitly authorizes the Maryland Stadium Authority to establish an Employee Stock Ownership Plan (ESOP) procurement preference program and requires the agency to report on its effectiveness by December 2028.

The bill explicitly authorizes Morgan State University to establish an ESOP procurement preference program and requires the university to report on the dollar value of contracts awarded under this program.
The bill explicitly authorizes St. Mary's College of Maryland to establish an ESOP procurement preference program and mandates reporting on its usage during the pilot period.

The bill explicitly includes the University System of Maryland as a 'unit' and 'university' authorized to implement the ESOP preference program and requires the system to submit reports to the General Assembly regarding its implementation.
The bill requires the Board of Public Works to approve the evaluation factors (up to 10%) established by the authorized units for their ESOP preference programs.

The Comptroller is a member of the Board of Public Works, which must approve the evaluation factors established under the bill. The agency also serves as the state's chief financial officer monitoring revenue and expenditure patterns.

The State Treasurer is a member of the Board of Public Works, which is responsible for approving the evaluation factors authorized by the bill. The office also manages state funds that will be used for these procurements.
The Governor's Office oversees the executive branch units authorized to implement this pilot and is a member of the Board of Public Works, which must approve the program's preferences.

As the central procurement authority for the state, DGS is responsible for the overall integrity of state procurement laws and was consulted regarding the fiscal impact of this new preference program.
The OAG provides legal counsel to the implementing agencies and the Board of Public Works regarding the legality and implementation of the new procurement preference regulations.
DBM oversees budget execution and long-term fiscal planning. The bill has a fiscal impact on state expenditures, as contracts may increase in cost by up to 10% due to the evaluation preference.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Small, Minority & Women Business Affairs
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This office monitors and implements the state's socioeconomic procurement programs; while ESOP is a new category, it functions similarly to the MBE and SBR programs managed by GOSBA.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes regulatory requirements for health insurance carriers, pharmacy benefits managers (PBMs), and private review agents (PRAs) that use artificial intelligence (AI), algorithms, or software tools for utilization review. It mandates that these tools base determinations on individual clinical circumstances rather than group datasets, ensures AI does not replace the role of health care providers in decision-making, and requires carriers to report whether such tools were used in making adverse decisions. The Maryland Insurance Commissioner is also authorized to audit and inspect these tools for compliance and accuracy.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Insurance Administration
qa_results.stakeholders: Health insurance carriers, pharmacy benefits managers, private review agents, health insurance enrollees, and health care providers.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State special fund revenues increase minimally starting in fiscal 2026 due to $1,500 filing fees for private review agent applications. State special fund expenditures increase by an indeterminate but potentially significant amount for contractual services to conduct compliance oversight of AI tools, though these costs may be passed on to the carriers, PBMs, and PRAs under examination. There is no local fiscal impact.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland Insurance Administration is the primary regulator responsible for enforcing the bill's requirements, drafting new regulations, reviewing pharmacy benefits manager and private review agent filings, and conducting audits of the artificial intelligence tools used for utilization review.

The Department of Health provides data to the Insurance Commissioner regarding health maintenance organizations for the required reports and is broadly responsible for health policy and Medicaid administration, which are impacted by changes in utilization review standards.

The Governor's Office is mandated by the bill to receive an annual summary report from the Insurance Commissioner regarding adverse decisions and grievances, specifically those involving the use of artificial intelligence.

As the administrator of the state's health insurance marketplace, the Exchange is directly impacted by changes in carrier utilization review practices, as these practices affect the accessibility and reliability of health coverage for its enrollees.

The Commission is responsible for planning the state's health system needs and improving accountability; regulation of AI in medical determinations is central to their mission of improving the quality and cost of health services.

The Office of the Attorney General serves as legal counsel to the Maryland Insurance Administration and would be involved in interpreting and defending the bill's standards regarding unfair discrimination and legal compliance for AI tools.

As the state's lead agency for IT strategy and security, DoIT may provide technical standards or guidance related to the audit and inspection of the machine-based systems and algorithms defined in the bill.

As the state's fiscal agency, DBM is affected by the Maryland Insurance Administration's need for contractual subject matter experts and potential fiscal impacts on the state employee health insurance program.

The HSCRC regulates hospital rates and population health outcomes; AI-driven changes in insurance utilization review, such as inpatient hospitalization denials, can impact hospital financial stability and patient care.
The Retirement Agency manages health benefit plans for over 420,000 members; the carriers providing these plans will be subject to the bill's new AI utilization review and reporting requirements.

OLA is responsible for auditing the Maryland Insurance Administration's performance and compliance; they will likely oversee MIA's implementation of the new regulatory and audit protocols for AI software.

The bill explicitly prohibits the use of AI tools that result in unfair discrimination prohibited by state law; the Commission on Civil Rights enforces anti-discrimination laws and may coordinate on issues of algorithmic bias.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill expands the membership of the Maryland Small Business Retirement Savings Board by adding the Comptroller, or the Comptroller’s designee, as a member.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Small Business Retirement Savings Board
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland small business employers and employees, the Maryland Small Business Retirement Savings Board, and the Comptroller's Office.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: According to the fiscal note, the bill has no effect on State or local finances. Adding the Comptroller or a designee as a member to the Maryland Small Business Retirement Savings Board does not affect State expenditures or revenues.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill specifically adds the Comptroller, or the Comptroller's designee, as a formal member of the Maryland Small Business Retirement Savings Board.
MarylandSaves is administered by the Maryland Small Business Retirement Savings Board; this bill directly alters the composition and membership of its governing board.
The Secretary of Labor is an existing ex-officio member of the board, and the bill amends the Labor and Employment Article of the Maryland Code which governs this program.
The State Treasurer is an existing ex-officio member of the Maryland Small Business Retirement Savings Board, which the bill is expanding.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill repeals the inactive Interdepartmental Advisory Committee on Small, Minority, and Women Business Affairs and establishes the Governor’s Subcabinet on Socioeconomic Procurement Participation. The new Subcabinet is responsible for studying socioeconomic procurement best practices, developing accountability measures for state agencies, and recommending statutory or regulatory reforms to improve the Minority Business Enterprise, Small Business Reserve, and Veteran Small Business Enterprise programs.
qa_results.responsible_party: Governor’s Office of Small, Minority, and Women Business Affairs (GOSBA)
qa_results.stakeholders: Small, minority, and women-owned businesses; veteran-owned businesses; and Maryland State executive departments and agencies involved in procurement.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The Fiscal Note indicates that the bill has no effect on State revenues and can be implemented by the Governor’s Office using existing resources. There is no fiscal impact on local governments.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Small, Minority & Women Business Affairs
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the primary implementing agency, the Special Secretary of the Office chairs the new Governor's Subcabinet on Socioeconomic Procurement Participation and oversees the repeal of the previous Interdepartmental Advisory Committee.

The Secretary of General Services and the Chief Procurement Officer are mandated members of the Subcabinet. Additionally, the Subcabinet is tasked with working specifically with the Office of State Procurement, which is housed within DGS, to improve contracting opportunities.

The Subcabinet is established within the Executive Department. The Governor receives its annual reports, may appoint additional agency heads to the body, and GOSBA functions as a unit within the Governor's Office.
The Secretary of Budget and Management is a mandated member of the Governor's Subcabinet on Socioeconomic Procurement Participation.
The Secretary of Commerce is a mandated member of the Governor's Subcabinet on Socioeconomic Procurement Participation.
The Secretary of Health is a mandated member of the Governor's Subcabinet on Socioeconomic Procurement Participation.
The Secretary of Housing and Community Development is a mandated member of the Governor's Subcabinet on Socioeconomic Procurement Participation.
The Secretary of Human Services is a mandated member of the Governor's Subcabinet on Socioeconomic Procurement Participation.
The Secretary of Information Technology is a mandated member of the Governor's Subcabinet on Socioeconomic Procurement Participation.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Secretary of Public Safety and Correctional Services is a mandated member of the Governor's Subcabinet on Socioeconomic Procurement Participation.
The Secretary of Transportation is a mandated member of the Governor's Subcabinet on Socioeconomic Procurement Participation.
The Secretary of Veterans and Military Families is a mandated member of the Governor's Subcabinet on Socioeconomic Procurement Participation.

The bill alters the definition of 'minority person' as it pertains to sheltered workshops for individuals with disabilities, which falls under the department's mission of improving services and opportunities for these residents.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill formally repeals one interdepartmental advisory committee and establishes a new subcabinet/committee within the executive branch.
The Subcabinet will recommend actions to improve socioeconomic procurement programs, which directly impacts the Board's oversight of significant state procurement contracts and expenditures.
The OAG provides legal counsel to state agencies and will be involved in the drafting and review of statutory and regulatory reforms recommended by the Subcabinet.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill expands the authority of the Carroll County Department of Human Resources to request State and national criminal history records checks for all prospective employees and volunteers, removing the previous limitation that restricted these checks to specific positions such as those involving inspections, financial handling, or the supervision of minors.
qa_results.responsible_party: Carroll County Department of Human Resources
qa_results.stakeholders: Prospective employees and volunteers of Carroll County
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: According to the fiscal note, the bill has no State fiscal impact as the Criminal Justice Information System Central Repository can handle the requirements with existing resources. For Carroll County, there is a potential minimal annual increase in expenditures beginning in fiscal 2026 to cover the costs of additional criminal history records checks, which currently cost $50 per applicant (including a $20 fingerprinting fee, a $12 FBI fee, and an $18 State fee). County revenues are not affected.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The agency is responsible for overseeing the Criminal Justice Information System Central Repository (CJIS-CR), which is the entity designated to receive and process the State and national criminal history records checks expanded by this bill.

The Governor's Office is the head of the executive branch and is responsible for the final approval and signing of the bill into law; it also oversees the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services, which manages the criminal record repository.

The bill modifies the existing law regarding criminal history records checks for prospective employees and volunteers assigned to work in the circuit court, for which this agency provides administrative and operational support.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill authorizes the County Commissioners of Carroll County to borrow up to $36,900,000 through the issuance of general obligation bonds to finance the acquisition, construction, and improvement of various public facilities, including schools, roads, water and sewer infrastructure, and loans for volunteer fire department equipment and facilities.
qa_results.responsible_party: County Commissioners of Carroll County
qa_results.stakeholders: Residents of Carroll County, public school system, Carroll Community College, volunteer fire departments, and agricultural landowners.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The State has no fiscal impact. Carroll County receives up to $36,900,000 in bond proceeds, while county debt service expenditures are estimated to increase by approximately $2,600,000 annually over a 20-year period at an estimated interest rate of 3.72%.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill authorizes bond funding for significant public school construction and renovation projects, which the Interagency Commission on School Construction is responsible for overseeing and managing through the state's Capital Improvement Program.

The bond proceeds are authorized for use in acquiring agricultural land and woodland preservation easements, specifically involving the Maryland Agriculture Land Preservation Program (MALPP) which is overseen by this department.
The bill authorizes funding for water and sewer infrastructure facilities and watershed improvement projects (NPDES), which are regulated and supported by the Department of the Environment.
The bill declares the bonds, interest, and income derived from them to be exempt from State and local taxation, which directly involves the Comptroller's role as the state's principal tax collector.
The bill authorizes funds for the construction and improvement of Carroll Community College buildings and facilities, which fall under the coordinating and policy oversight of the Commission.
The bond includes funding for conservation and open space projects, which aligns with the department's mission of managing and enhancing Maryland's natural resources and public lands.
The bond allocates a significant portion of its funds (over $19 million) to public school facilities, which are under the leadership and oversight of the Maryland State Department of Education.
The bill authorizes loans to volunteer fire departments for fire or emergency-related equipment and facilities, supporting local jurisdiction resilience which is a core mission of the department.
The Department of Planning promotes sustainable growth and land use planning, including the agricultural and woodland preservation initiatives authorized by this bond measure.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill alters the regulations for Class B-Stadium (baseball stadium) alcoholic beverages licenses in Charles County. It prohibits the sale and consumption of alcohol in stadium parking areas, allows patrons to carry and consume liquor throughout the stadium premises (excluding parking areas) rather than just in dining areas, and updates authorized container types to include plastic, paper, or other nonglass containers while specifically removing Styrofoam.
qa_results.responsible_party: Charles County Board of License Commissioners
qa_results.stakeholders: Owners of professional baseball franchises, private concessionaires at stadiums in Charles County, and stadium patrons.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The Fiscal Note indicates there is no impact on State finances and the bill does not materially affect Charles County finances or operations. The annual license fee for the Class B-Stadium license is $2,200, but no change in revenue is anticipated. Small business impact is considered minimal.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Comptroller of Maryland is the principal state agency responsible for regulating the alcohol industry and enforcing related tax laws. This bill directly amends the state's Alcoholic Beverages and Cannabis Article concerning specific licensing regulations in Charles County.

The Office of the Attorney General serves as the chief legal officer for the state, providing legal counsel to the General Assembly and the Governor regarding the legality and interpretation of changes to the Maryland Code, including the Alcoholic Beverages and Cannabis Article.
The Governor's Office oversees the executive branch and has the final authority to sign bills into law or veto them. This bill was signed by the Governor as Chapter 784 of the 2025 Laws of Maryland.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes that the practice of direct-entry midwifery is an independent profession that does not require oversight by other health care practitioners. It updates the clinical conditions that require a midwife to either consult with a physician or transfer a patient's care, alters requirements for emergency transfer plans, repeals specific annual reporting mandates to the Direct-Entry Midwifery Advisory Committee, and extends the regulatory act for midwives through July 1, 2030.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland State Board of Nursing
qa_results.stakeholders: Licensed direct-entry midwives, pregnant individuals, and newborns.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The Department of Legislative Services reports that the bill's changes are technical in nature and do not directly affect state or local governmental finances. There are no specific revenue or expenditure figures provided in the Fiscal Note.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland Department of Health (MDH) is the primary agency responsible for regulating health care professionals. The bill directly impacts the State Board of Nursing (which is within MDH) by altering the licensing, scope of practice, and disciplinary procedures for direct-entry midwives.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill specifically mentions the Direct-Entry Midwifery Advisory Committee, altering its reporting requirements, plan review duties, and role in consultation with the Board of Nursing regarding reporting regulations.

The Office of the Attorney General provides legal counsel to the Board of Nursing and MDH. It would be involved in drafting and reviewing the new regulations mandated by the bill and representing the Board in legal challenges regarding disciplinary actions.

As the agency that adjudicates contested cases for state agencies, the OAH would likely handle hearings related to the altered disciplinary actions (reprimands, probation, suspensions) for licensed direct-entry midwives.

DBM is responsible for fiscal planning and oversight of the Maryland Program Evaluation Act (sunset law). The bill extends the termination date for the Maryland Licensure of Direct-Entry Midwives Act, which requires DBM's coordination for long-term fiscal planning and personnel management.

The bill's changes to disciplinary procedures and licensing may lead to judicial reviews of administrative decisions in the state's court system, which is supported by the Administrative Office of the Courts.

The Governor's Office oversees the executive branch and policy initiatives. This bill relates to the administration's policy on healthcare access and professional regulation, and it includes a sunset extension for an executive department program.

The MHCC is responsible for health system planning and improving access to care. Redefining the independence and scope of practice for midwives directly impacts the planning and availability of maternal health services in Maryland.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Health Care Alternative Dispute Resolution Office
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As health care practitioners, direct-entry midwives are subject to medical malpractice claims. The bill's changes to independent practice and scope could impact the nature of claims handled by this office's arbitration system.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland Institute for Emergency Medical Services Systems
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill outlines procedures for midwives during emergencies and transfers to hospitals, which involves coordination with the statewide emergency medical services network overseen by MIEMSS.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill allows a provisional ballot to be counted for nonpartisan board of education contests if the ballot was cast because the voter claimed a political party affiliation different from the one on record, provided the voter made a selection in such a contest. Local boards of canvassers are required to count only the votes in the nonpartisan board of education contest in these specific instances.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland State Board of Elections and local boards of canvassers
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland voters with party affiliation discrepancies and candidates for nonpartisan board of education seats
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: According to the Fiscal and Policy Note, the bill does not directly affect State finances and is not expected to materially affect local government finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland State Board of Elections is the primary agency responsible for supervising and administering elections in the state. This bill directly modifies election laws regarding the qualification and counting of provisional ballots for nonpartisan board of education contests, requiring the State Board to update regulations and oversee local boards of canvassers in implementing these procedural changes.

The Office of the Attorney General provides legal counsel to the State Board of Elections and local boards. It will be responsible for advising these entities on the legal interpretation of the new provisional ballot standards and representing the state in any litigation that may arise from the validation or rejection of ballots under these new rules.

The bill specifically affects the election of members to local boards of education, which are the governing bodies for the school systems overseen by the Maryland State Department of Education. Changes to how votes for these boards are validated and counted directly impact the governance structure of the state's public education system.

As the head of the executive branch, the Governor oversees the State Board of Elections and is responsible for signing or vetoing legislation that changes state election procedures and the governance of public institutions.

The Secretary of State is the official custodian of the state's laws and records. This department is responsible for recording the act once it is signed and maintaining the permanent records of state laws, including those governing the election process.

qa_results.bill_summary: The Pregnant and Parenting Student Support Act requires most Maryland public four-year higher education institutions to develop and publish a plan for supporting pregnant and parenting students. This plan must include referrals to government assistance programs (such as SNAP and the Child Care Scholarship Program), adoption services, and a network of health care providers, as well as institutional accommodations like priority registration and flexible scheduling.
qa_results.responsible_party: Public senior higher education institutions, including the constituent institutions of the University System of Maryland, Morgan State University, and St. Mary’s College of Maryland.
qa_results.stakeholders: Pregnant and parenting students enrolled at public senior higher education institutions in Maryland.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: Affected public senior higher education institutions can generally adopt and post the required plans using existing resources. However, higher education expenditures may increase by an unknown, but likely minimal to moderate amount, if additional services are provided. Additionally, state and federal expenditures for Medicaid and the Maryland Children’s Health Program may increase, potentially significantly, if referrals lead to more students receiving government assistance entitlements. Specific dollar estimates are not provided.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill explicitly identifies the constituent institutions of the University System of Maryland (with certain exceptions) as 'public senior higher education institutions' that must adopt and post plans for pregnant and parenting students.
The bill explicitly names Morgan State University as a 'public senior higher education institution' required to adopt and post a plan for pregnant and parenting students.
The bill explicitly names St. Mary's College of Maryland as a 'public senior higher education institution' required to adopt and post a plan for pregnant and parenting students.

The mandated plans must include referrals to the Maryland Medical Assistance Program (Medicaid) and the Maryland Children's Health Program (MCHP), both administered by MDH. The fiscal note indicates these referrals may significantly increase expenditures for these programs.
The required plans must provide referrals to government assistance programs such as food assistance (SNAP) and information regarding adoption services, which are primary responsibilities of DHS.
The mandated plans must include referrals to the Child Care Scholarship Program, which is managed by MSDE. Increased referrals could impact program administration and expenditures.

As the state's regulatory and coordinating board for higher education, MHEC oversees the institutions impacted by this bill and sets statewide policies that may be affected by these new plan requirements.
The fiscal note identifies potential impacts on the state budget and general fund expenditures due to increased enrollment in entitlement programs resulting from the bill's referral requirements.

The OAG provides legal counsel to state agencies and higher education institutions. It may be called upon to ensure the required plans comply with Title IX of the federal Higher Education Act and other anti-discrimination laws.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill repeals the Charles County Gaming Permit Review Board and transfers its powers and duties, including the review of gaming permit applications and recommendations for gaming regulations, to the County Attorney for Charles County.
qa_results.responsible_party: The County Attorney for Charles County and the Board of County Commissioners of Charles County
qa_results.stakeholders: Fundraising organizations in Charles County conducting gaming events, the Charles County government, and residents of Charles County
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: According to the Fiscal Note, the bill has no state fiscal impact. Locally, there is no fiscal impact because the Charles County Attorney has already assumed the duties and responsibilities of the now-repealed Gaming Permit Review Board.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill repeals the Charles County Gaming Permit Review Board, which by statute currently requires a member of the Department of State Police to serve on the board. This legislation removes that statutory requirement and service obligation.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland State Lottery & Gaming Control Agency
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the state's primary regulatory body for gaming, the agency monitors legislation affecting the gaming landscape and local oversight boards. The agency was also consulted as an information source for the bill's fiscal note.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The office coordinates public safety policy and monitors amendments to the Criminal Law Article, which includes the regulations and oversight mechanisms for local gaming activities in Charles County.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill increases the annual salaries for certain local officials in Somerset County, including the Sheriff, the County Commissioners, and members of the County Roads Board. The increases are slated to take effect at the beginning of the next term of office following the bill's effective date.
qa_results.responsible_party: Somerset County Government
qa_results.stakeholders: Somerset County public officials and taxpayers
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: According to the Fiscal Note, local expenditures in Somerset County will increase by at least $23,300 in fiscal 2027 and by a minimum of $40,000 annually thereafter. These figures represent the salary increases beginning with terms of office in December 2026 and do not account for fringe benefits. There is no impact on State operations or finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly amends the Courts and Judicial Proceedings Article of the Maryland Code to adjust the salary of the Sheriff of Somerset County, a role that functions as an officer of the judicial system.
As the chief executive, the Governor's Office oversees intergovernmental relations with local jurisdictions and signed this local salary legislation into law.
The Office of the Attorney General provides legal counsel on the constitutionality of bill provisions, particularly those concerning the salaries of constitutional and local officials.
Salary increases for local officials such as Sheriffs and Commissioners often affect the pension calculations and liabilities within the state-administered retirement systems.
The Secretary of State is the official custodian of state records and laws, responsible for recording and maintaining the laws enacted by the General Assembly.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires health insurance carriers and private review agents to provide enhanced notices regarding adverse decisions (denials) and grievance results. These notices must include bold warnings, unique identifiers for the medical directors making the decisions, and dedicated contact information. The bill also mandates that carriers report adverse decision data to the Maryland Insurance Commissioner aggregated by zip code and provide detailed explanations when denial rates for specific services increase by 10% annually or 25% over three years. Additionally, private review agents must post their clinical review criteria on dedicated member and provider website pages and respond to inquiries within two business days.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Insurance Commissioner
qa_results.stakeholders: Health insurance members and their representatives, health care providers, health insurance carriers, and private review agents.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: According to the Fiscal Note, any administrative impact on the Maryland Insurance Administration to implement the reporting and examination requirements can be absorbed within existing budgeted resources. There is no impact on state revenues or local government finances. Specific dollar estimates for the compliance costs incurred by private health insurance carriers and review agents are not provided in the fiscal analysis.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland Insurance Administration is the primary regulatory agency for this bill. The Insurance Commissioner is responsible for receiving and analyzing quarterly reports from carriers, determining the form of these reports, monitoring growth in adverse decisions, and conducting examinations of carriers based on the submitted data.

The bill requires all adverse decision and grievance notices to include the contact information for the Health Advocacy Unit, which is a division of the Office of the Attorney General. The Health Advocacy Unit is responsible for assisting members in mediating and filing grievances with insurance carriers.

The bill applies to health insurance carriers, which include Health Maintenance Organizations (HMOs). The Secretary of Health is required by law to provide information regarding HMOs to the Insurance Commissioner for the annual summary report on appeals and grievances mentioned in the bill.

The Exchange administers the state's health insurance marketplace. Since the bill mandates new notice and reporting requirements for all carriers regarding adverse decisions (denials) and grievances, it directly impacts the consumer protection standards and member communications for the private plans sold through the Exchange.

The Governor's Office is relevant as the Maryland Insurance Commissioner is required to submit an annual summary report to the Governor detailing the grievances and adverse decisions handled by carriers across the state.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes the Workgroup on the Creation of a Data Dashboard for Public Work Contracts and Apprentices. The workgroup is tasked with studying the most efficient and cost-effective methods to develop a publicly available data dashboard that tracks information regarding State public work contracts. This information includes details on contractors, subcontractors, employee wages and benefits, and comprehensive data on apprentices, such as their demographics, trade, and certification status. The workgroup must report its findings and recommendations to the Governor and the General Assembly by January 7, 2027.
qa_results.responsible_party: Workgroup on the Creation of a Data Dashboard for Public Work Contracts and Apprentices, with staffing provided by the Maryland Department of Labor
qa_results.stakeholders: Contractors, subcontractors, employees, and apprentices engaged in Maryland State public work contracts; the Maryland Department of Labor; and various construction and labor organizations.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The Maryland Department of Labor can staff the workgroup with existing resources. Expense reimbursements for workgroup members are expected to be minimal and absorbable within current budget allocations. The bill has no effect on State revenues or local government finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Secretary of Labor and the Commissioner of Labor and Industry are designated members of the Workgroup. Additionally, the Commissioner is responsible for providing staff to the Workgroup, and the department oversees the apprenticeship registration data mentioned in the study requirements.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill creates the Workgroup on the Creation of a Data Dashboard for Public Work Contracts and Apprentices, which is a temporary body tasked with conducting a study and providing recommendations.
The Governor is responsible for appointing six members to the Workgroup and will receive the final report containing findings and recommendations.
The Board of Public Works oversees and approves the significant state procurement contracts and expenditures that would be tracked and reported on the proposed data dashboard.
As the primary operational support and procurement agency for state public works and construction, DGS manages many of the contracts that will be analyzed by the Workgroup.
MDOT manages a high volume of public works projects through its modal administrations, making it a primary source of data and an entity impacted by dashboard reporting recommendations.
The IAC oversees public school construction projects, which are a major category of public works identified in the fiscal note as subject to prevailing wage and apprenticeship requirements.
The Office of Appointments will assist the Governor in recruiting and vetting the six members from various trade and contractor organizations specifically required by the bill.
The Workgroup is tasked with studying the creation of a publicly available data dashboard, which directly involves state information technology strategy and digital infrastructure managed by DoIT.
GOPI focuses on utilizing data-driven strategies and performance metrics to enhance state government accountability and transparency, aligning with the purpose of a public works dashboard.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Small, Minority & Women Business Affairs
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The study includes disaggregating information on subcontractors and apprentice demographics, which is highly relevant to this office's mission of monitoring socioeconomic procurement programs.
The board coordinates workforce solutions including apprenticeships, which are a central focus of the data transparency study mandated by the bill.
The MLDS Center links student and workforce data; the proposed dashboard's collection of apprentice demographic and registration data overlaps with their analytical functions.
The MSA manages significant public works projects and is identified in the fiscal note as a source of information regarding prevailing wage and contract administration.
The department collaborates on youth apprenticeship programs mentioned in the context of the bill's apprenticeship data requirements.
As a state entity that manages its own construction and urban research projects, the university is identified as a relevant stakeholder in public works compliance.
As an independent public college that manages its own construction projects, it is identified as a relevant stakeholder in public works compliance.
The USM manages public works across its network of institutions and is identified as a relevant stakeholder regarding contract and prevailing wage reporting.

qa_results.bill_summary: The Maryland Second Look Act expands the Juvenile Restoration Act to allow individuals who committed certain crimes between the ages of 18 and 25 to petition a court for a sentence reduction after serving at least 20 years of their term. To be eligible, the individual must not be a sex offender, must not be serving life without parole, and must not have been convicted of murdering a first responder in the line of duty. The bill also establishes several victim protections, including the right to provide impact statements without cross-examination and mandatory stay-away orders upon an individual's release.
qa_results.responsible_party: Office of the Public Defender
qa_results.stakeholders: Incarcerated individuals who committed crimes as young adults (ages 18 to 24) and have served 20 years, crime victims and their representatives, the Office of the Public Defender, and State's Attorneys' offices.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund expenditures for the Office of the Public Defender increase by a minimum of $538,100 in FY 2026 to hire six staff members (four attorneys, one social worker, and one administrative employee), with annual costs projected to reach $730,300 by FY 2030. State expenditures for the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services will decrease by approximately $312 per month for every individual released from incarceration. Local expenditures for State's Attorneys' offices may increase minimally to handle the processing of new petitions.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill establishes judicial procedures for individuals to file motions to reduce sentences in circuit courts. The Judicial Branch is responsible for conducting the required hearings and issuing written decisions based on specified factors.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland Office of the Public Defender
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The fiscal note identifies a direct increase in general fund expenditures for the Office of the Public Defender (minimum of $538,100 in FY 2026) to hire attorneys, social workers, and staff to handle the increased volume of sentencing reduction motions.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill affects the incarcerated population managed by DPSCS. The department is expected to see a decrease in expenditures if individuals are released early, and it will be involved in reporting institutional compliance to the courts.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the primary coordinating body for public safety and criminal justice strategies, this agency is relevant to the implementation of sentencing reforms and the management of victim services mentioned in the bill.

DBM is responsible for state budget development and personnel management. It must manage the fiscal impact of increased staffing for the Office of the Public Defender and the potential savings within DPSCS.

The bill requires courts to consider reports from health professionals regarding an individual's physical, mental, or behavioral health. Additionally, the bill references definitions of 'first responder' within the Health - General Article.
The bill requires courts to consider an individual's history in the child welfare system as a factor for sentence reduction, which is an area managed and documented by DHS.
The OAG serves as legal counsel to the state agencies impacted by this bill, including DPSCS and the Department of Health, and monitors changes to criminal procedure.
The Governor's Office oversees the executive branch agencies implementing the bill and coordinates high-level criminal justice policy and budget proposals affected by these changes.

The office focuses on child well-being and reducing poverty; the bill's consideration of childhood trauma and child welfare history aligns with the office's mission to address historical underinvestment and social outcomes.

The bill excludes certain offenses from sentence reduction, specifically murder of first responders (which includes state police) in the line of duty, and relates to general public safety enforcement.

The bill expands the Juvenile Restoration Act, and while the new eligibility targets young adults (18-24), DJS maintains expertise and records regarding individuals previously involved in the juvenile justice system.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill modifies the composition of the Workgroup on Establishing a Science and Technology Best Practices and Innovation Network by reducing the number of required members from various sectors. It also extends the workgroup's existence and its reporting deadline to the Governor and General Assembly by two years, with a final termination date of June 30, 2027.
qa_results.responsible_party: University of Maryland, Baltimore County
qa_results.stakeholders: Citizen scientists, science and technology experts, Maryland institutions of higher education (including historically Black colleges and universities and community colleges), private sector technology entities, and nonprofit advocacy organizations.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: According to the Fiscal Note, the workgroup's activities for the extended two-year period can be supported with existing budgeted resources. There is no impact on State revenues or local government finances.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly relates to the membership, duration, and reporting requirements of the Workgroup on Establishing a Science and Technology Best Practices and Innovation Network, which falls under this category.
The University of Maryland, Baltimore County (UMBC), a member of the USM, is explicitly required to provide staff for the Workgroup and has a designated representative on the Workgroup.
The Executive Director of TEDCO (or their designee) is a named member of the Workgroup, which focuses on science and technology innovation.
The Governor is responsible for appointing several members of the Workgroup and receiving the Workgroup's final report on science and technology best practices.
The Office of Appointments assists the Governor in recruiting and vetting candidates for the positions on the Workgroup that the Governor is authorized to appoint.

The bill requires the Governor to appoint a representative from a historically Black college or university (HBCU) to the Workgroup; as Maryland's preeminent urban research university and an HBCU, Morgan State is a primary candidate for this role.
As an independent public honors college, Saint Mary's College of Maryland may be considered for the higher education representative positions on the Workgroup.
The Workgroup includes multiple representatives from institutions of higher education (community colleges, HBCUs, and independent institutions), sectors that are regulated and coordinated by MHEC.
The bill stipulates that Workgroup members are entitled to reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, which are overseen by DBM.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill allows authorized hunters who wound a deer during legal hunting hours to pursue and kill that deer after legal hunting hours. It specifically permits the use of artificial lights, such as spotlights or headlights, during the pursuit, provided the hunter uses the means authorized for the applicable hunting season.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Natural Resources
qa_results.stakeholders: Licensed deer hunters in Maryland
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The Fiscal and Policy Note indicates that the bill does not directly affect State or local finances. No specific revenue changes, expenditures, or mandates were identified.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: DNR is the primary agency responsible for managing Maryland's wildlife and hunting programs. The bill specifically authorizes DNR to oversee deer hunting activities and mandates that the department adopt regulations to implement the new provisions regarding the pursuit of wounded deer after hours with the use of artificial lights.

The OAG provides legal counsel to state agencies, including DNR. They will be involved in the review and drafting of the regulations required by the bill to ensure they are legally sound and consistent with existing state and federal law.

As a primary law enforcement agency, the Maryland State Police may encounter individuals using lights to track animals after hours. They need to be aware of this legal exception to avoid issuing citations for prohibited hunting practices (such as 'shining') when a hunter is acting within the new authorized scope of the law.

The judicial branch adjudicates violations of the Natural Resources Article. Changes to hunting hours and methods create new legal defenses or exceptions that judges and court staff must be aware of when handling cases related to illegal night hunting or the use of lights.

The Governor oversees the executive branch, including the Department of Natural Resources, and is responsible for signing the bill into law and ensuring the executive agencies implement the mandated regulations.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland Health Benefit Exchange (MHBE), in collaboration with the Maryland State Department of Education (MSDE), to promote health insurance access for child care professionals. MHBE must partner with relevant organizations to help child care professionals enroll in Medicaid or exchange plans, provide outreach and informational resources, and conduct a survey to assess health care access within the child care provider community.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Health Benefit Exchange
qa_results.stakeholders: Child care professionals, child care employers, and prekindergarten providers
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State special fund expenditures increase by a total of $500,000 in fiscal 2026, which includes a $250,000 transfer from the Department of Commerce's Child Care Capital Support Revolving Loan Fund and $250,000 in spending by the Maryland Health Benefit Exchange (MHBE) for outreach and a survey. MHBE special fund revenues increase by $250,000 in fiscal 2026 due to the transfer. There is no impact on local government finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland Health Benefit Exchange is the primary agency responsible for implementing the bill's requirements, including conducting a targeted outreach campaign to help child care professionals enroll in health insurance and performing a survey of health care access in the child care community.

The bill requires the Maryland Health Benefit Exchange to partner with the State Department of Education for outreach efforts and consult with them on the development of a survey regarding health care access. It also utilizes MSDE definitions for prekindergarten provider hubs and child care scholarship vouchers.

The fiscal note indicates a notable impact on the Department of Commerce, as $250,000 will be transferred from the department's Child Care Capital Support Revolving Loan Fund to the Maryland Health Benefit Exchange to fund the outreach campaign and survey.

The bill's outreach efforts are specifically designed to help child care professionals obtain Medicaid and assist those who lose Medicaid coverage in finding alternative options; the Department of Health administers the state's Medicaid program.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill prohibits private common carriers from damaging public bridges or highways such that they must be closed. It defines such damage as a public nuisance and allows the State or local governments to seek injunctive relief, repair costs, and daily civil penalties through civil action.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Transportation, Maryland Transportation Authority, and local governments
qa_results.stakeholders: Common carriers (including bus, railroad, taxi, and transportation network companies), the Maryland Department of Transportation, and local governments
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State and local revenues may increase due to civil penalties of $1,000 per day and compensatory damages for infrastructure repair. State Transportation Trust Fund and local government expenditures may decrease if repair costs are recovered, though legal expenses for litigation may increase. The total impact is indeterminate as it depends on future incidents of damage.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Governor's Office oversees the executive branch and signed the bill into law; however, its direct operational role in nuisance litigation regarding infrastructure is minimal.
The Comptroller's Office is the state's chief financial officer; civil penalties and compensatory damages recovered by the State under this bill would contribute to state revenue funds.
The Treasurer's Office manages and protects state funds and property, and was identified as an information source regarding the fiscal impacts of state infrastructure protection.

The OAG is the primary legal representative for the State and would be responsible for bringing civil actions for public nuisance, seeking injunctive relief, and recovery of damages on behalf of state agencies.
DBM oversees the state's budget execution and revenue estimation; the bill potentially impacts the General Fund through civil penalties and the Transportation Trust Fund through damage recovery.

MDOT is the primary agency responsible for the state's transportation network, including the highways and bridges defined as 'public infrastructure' under the bill. It would likely be the principal agency for which the State brings nuisance actions.
MSP is responsible for traffic safety and law enforcement on state highways; they would likely be involved in investigating incidents of infrastructure damage that necessitate closures.
The bill creates new civil causes of action within the Courts and Judicial Proceedings Article, impacting court operations and the judiciary's workload for adjudicating these cases.
As a modal administration of MDOT, the MTA maintains transit-related public infrastructure that would be protected by the provisions of this bill.
The MDTA operates and maintains the state's toll bridges and facilities; the fiscal note specifically identifies potential nonbudgeted expenditure impacts for MDTA to litigate these nuisance cases.
The PSC regulates many of the 'common carriers' defined in the bill, including taxicabs, passenger motor vehicle carriers, and railroads, ensuring their safe operation.
SHA is the MDOT agency specifically responsible for non-toll state highways and bridges, which constitute a significant portion of the 'public infrastructure' protected by the bill.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires transportation network companies to provide each operator with a weekly fare and earnings summary that includes total fares, fees, and operator earnings as a percentage of those totals. It also mandates that companies submit an annual report to the Maryland Public Service Commission containing aggregated data on average fares, total drive time, and total operator earnings.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Public Service Commission
qa_results.stakeholders: Transportation network companies and transportation network operators (drivers)
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The Maryland Public Service Commission can implement the bill using existing budgeted resources. There is no estimated impact on State or local revenues or local expenditures.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Public Service Commission is the primary regulatory authority responsible for overseeing transportation network companies (TNCs). The bill requires TNCs to report fare and operator data to the Commission and tasks the Commission with determining the form of demographic data and compiling an annual report.
The bill explicitly requires the Public Service Commission to report the compiled TNC operator and fare data to the Department of Transportation on an annual basis.
As the head of the executive branch, the Governor's Office oversees the Public Service Commission. The bill was also signed into law by the Governor.

The Office of the Attorney General provides legal counsel to state agencies like the Public Service Commission. They would likely be involved in ensuring the confidentiality and trade secret protections mandated by the bill are upheld.

The bill focuses on the earnings, fares, and demographic data of transportation network operators, which relates to the Department of Labor's mission to protect workers and monitor workforce development and adult learning programs.

qa_results.bill_summary: The bill authorizes the transfer of funds from the Catastrophic Event Account to the State Disaster Recovery Fund when the latter's funds are depleted or insufficient for disaster relief. It also shortens the Legislative Policy Committee's review period for such transfers from 15 to 10 days.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Governor, Department of Budget and Management, and Maryland Department of Emergency Management
qa_results.stakeholders: State and local government agencies and Maryland residents affected by natural disasters or catastrophic events
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill results in a potential shift of special funds. Special fund expenditures from the Catastrophic Event Account (which has a projected FY 2026 balance of 10,000,000) would increase, while special fund revenues for the State Disaster Recovery Fund would increase by the same amount. There is no net impact on State finances. Interest revenue to the Revenue Stabilization Account (Rainy Day Fund) may decrease minimally. Local governments may benefit from faster access to disaster recovery funds.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: DBM is the principal fiscal agency for Maryland and is responsible for administering the Catastrophic Event Account. This bill directly modifies the administrative procedures and authorized uses for funds within that account, including the timeframe for budget amendments.

MDEM administers the State Disaster Recovery Fund. This bill authorizes the transfer of funds from the Catastrophic Event Account to the State Disaster Recovery Fund under specific conditions, directly impacting the resources available to MDEM for disaster response.

The bill grants the Governor the authority to transfer funds between these accounts via budget amendment and reduces the required review period for such transfers, directly affecting the Governor's executive powers during disasters.

The bill explicitly mandates that the Comptroller shall account for the Catastrophic Event Account. As the state's chief financial officer, any change to fund transfer mechanisms and accounting for disaster-related reserves falls under the Comptroller's purview.
The bill explicitly requires the State Treasurer to hold the Catastrophic Event Account and dictates that the account be invested and reinvested in the same manner as other State funds.

As the chief legal officer for the state, the OAG provides legal counsel to the Governor and executive agencies regarding the implementation of statutory changes and the execution of budget amendments and fund transfers authorized by this bill.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes a Class C (theater) beer, wine, and liquor license in Frederick County, authorizing the Board of License Commissioners to issue the license to theaters with seating for on-premises consumption during and around performances, fundraisers, and rented events.
qa_results.responsible_party: Frederick County Board of License Commissioners
qa_results.stakeholders: Theaters with seating in Frederick County and their patrons
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: Frederick County revenues will increase starting in fiscal 2026 based on the number of $150 annual licenses issued. Enforcement will be managed by the county using existing resources, and there is no impact on State finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Comptroller is the state's principal regulator of the alcohol industry. While the license is issued by a local board, the agency oversees industry compliance and state-level regulations within the Alcoholic Beverages and Cannabis Article.

The Department of Commerce oversees the state's arts and tourism sectors. This bill directly impacts the business operations and economic viability of theaters, which are classified as arts and cultural venues under the agency's purview.

The Office of Tourism Development promotes Maryland’s cultural and recreational attractions. The establishment of a theater-specific liquor license enhances the visitor experience and the competitive appeal of these venues to tourists.

The Office of the Attorney General provides legal counsel to the General Assembly and state boards. They are responsible for interpreting the state's Alcoholic Beverages and Cannabis Article and ensuring that local legislation adheres to state law.
As the head of the executive branch, the Governor signed this bill into law and is responsible for the overall oversight of the state's regulatory framework regarding alcoholic beverages.

qa_results.bill_summary: The bill permanently allows audio-only phone calls to count as telehealth and ensures doctors are paid the same for telehealth as they are for in-person visits under Medicaid and private insurance. It also allows certain pain medications to be prescribed via telehealth if the patient has seen the doctor in person before and requires regular reports on telehealth trends.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Health Care Commission, Maryland Department of Health (Medicaid), and Maryland Insurance Administration
qa_results.stakeholders: Health care providers, patients, Medicaid recipients, and private health insurance carriers
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: Special fund expenditures for the Maryland Health Care Commission increase by $100,000 every four years starting in FY 2027 to complete required reports. Medicaid expenditures and federal fund revenues for telehealth services will continue beyond FY 2025, though the overall fiscal impact is indeterminate. Special fund revenues for the Maryland Insurance Administration decrease minimally in FY 2026 only.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the agency that manages state employee benefits and personnel policies, DBM oversees the State Employee and Retiree Health and Welfare Benefits Program, which is subject to the health insurance mandates regarding telehealth coverage and reimbursement parity.

MDH administers the Maryland Medical Assistance Program (Medicaid), which is required by this bill to permanently include audio-only interactions in its definition of telehealth and to reimburse telehealth services at the same rate as in-person services.

The Governor's Office receives the quadrennial reports from the Maryland Health Care Commission mandated by the bill. Additionally, the Governor's authority to declare a state of emergency is a factor in the conditions under which Schedule II opiates may be prescribed via telehealth.
The bill explicitly preserves the authority of the HSCRC to set appropriate hospital rates and facility fees for telehealth services provided by hospitals.
The bill mandates that the MHCC submit a report to the Governor and General Assembly every four years regarding advances in telehealth delivery and changes in associated costs.
The MIA is responsible for regulating the insurers, nonprofit health service plans, and HMOs that are mandated by the bill to provide permanent telehealth coverage and reimbursement parity.

The OCSA enforces the state's Controlled Dangerous Substance Act and regulates the prescribing of drugs. This bill alters the specific legal circumstances under which practitioners can prescribe Schedule II opiates via telehealth.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill expands the definition of 'community benefit' for nonprofit hospitals to include community health worker workforce programs created in partnership with community-based organizations. These programs focus on improving patient health and addressing social factors that affect health. The bill sets standards for agreements between hospitals and organizations, including responsibilities for training and providing health insurance to workers.
qa_results.responsible_party: Health Services Cost Review Commission
qa_results.stakeholders: Nonprofit hospitals, community-based organizations, community health workers, and hospital patients in Maryland
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no direct effect on State or local government finances. It permits nonprofit hospitals to count community health worker programs as community benefits, which may involve private financial agreements between hospitals and community groups, but no specific dollar estimates are provided by the Fiscal Note.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill explicitly modifies the definition of 'community benefit' used by the Commission to regulate hospital rates and revenues. The Commission is responsible for collecting the annual community benefit reports that will now include these workforce programs.

The Commission is an independent unit within the MDH, and the MDH is responsible for certifying community health workers (CHWs) and overseeing the state's public health policy, including social determinants of health mentioned in the bill.
The bill includes provisions regarding employer-sponsored health insurance coverage for community health workers, a matter regulated by the MIA. The agency was also consulted for the fiscal note.

The OAG serves as legal counsel to the MDH and the Commission, and will likely be involved in reviewing the legal framework for the memoranda of understanding (MOUs) and ensuring compliance with federal and state laws like HIPAA mentioned in the bill.

As a regulatory agency within MDH focused on planning state health system needs and improving access to care, the MHCC's work overlaps with the bill's goal of improving health outcomes and addressing social determinants through new workforce programs.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill references the 'Community Benefit Reporting Workgroup,' an entity falling under this category that will be responsible for incorporating the new program definition into reporting standards.

The bill establishes a specific health worker workforce program, which aligns with the board's mission to develop workforce solutions and coordinate partnerships to ensure pathways to prosperity and meaningful employment.
The bill creates a workforce program for community health workers; the Department of Labor oversees workforce development and licensing of various professions in the state.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Service and Civic Innovation
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This agency creates workforce pathways and partnerships between non-profits and government agencies, which is the core mechanism of the community health worker workforce programs defined in the bill.
CHW programs are intended to address social determinants of health, which falls under DHS's mission of assisting residents in economic need and providing preventative aid.

The bill targets social determinants of health through community-based partnerships; DHCD is involved in community revitalization and improving the quality of life and economic vitality in Maryland communities.
The GOC focuses on access to health services and economic opportunities for underinvested communities, goals that align with the patient outreach and social determinant focus of CHW programs.
The bill includes requirements for health insurance coverage for CHWs; the MHBE administers the marketplace and determines eligibility for financial assistance for health coverage.
The GOCI facilitates partnerships between the state, nonprofits, and community organizations to address local needs, which is the exact model of the CHW workforce programs described in the bill.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill clarifies that liability for failure to comply with requirements regarding a tenant's right of first refusal to purchase a residential property is restricted to the owner of the property and does not attach to the property itself once a contract of sale between the owner and a third party has closed.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Housing and Community Development (Office of Tenant and Landlord Affairs)
qa_results.stakeholders: Residential rental property owners and tenants.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill does not affect State or local government finances or operations, as stated in the formal Fiscal Note.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly involves the Office of Tenant and Landlord Affairs (OTLA), which is housed within the Department of Housing and Community Development (DHCD). The bill requires owners to send notices of the right of first refusal to OTLA and tasks the Secretary of Housing and Community Development with establishing regulations for the form of these notices.

The bill clarifies legal liability regarding real property transfers and tenant rights. As the agency supporting the Maryland Judicial Branch, the Administrative Office of the Courts is relevant because disputes regarding compliance with the right of first refusal and the attachment of liability to property owners rather than the property itself would be adjudicated within the state court system.

The Office of the Attorney General provides legal counsel to state agencies like DHCD and oversees consumer protection. This bill involves property law and tenant rights, areas where the OAG may provide legal guidance on regulation implementation or enforcement.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill extends the termination date and reporting deadlines for the Prison Education Delivery Reform Commission by three years. The commission's interim report is now due by June 1, 2028, and its final report is due by January 1, 2029, with the commission scheduled to sunset on June 30, 2029.
qa_results.responsible_party: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
qa_results.stakeholders: Adult offenders in the criminal and juvenile justice systems, the Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy, and the Maryland General Assembly.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund expenditures will increase by an estimated total of $204,600 from fiscal year 2026 through fiscal year 2029 to maintain a contractual program coordinator to support the commission's extended operations. Specifically, costs are projected at $28,500 in FY 2026, $65,600 in FY 2027, $68,400 in FY 2028, and $42,100 in FY 2029. There is no fiscal impact in FY 2025, and no material effect on local government finances.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: GOCPP is the primary agency responsible for staffing the Prison Education Delivery Reform Commission and will incur a direct fiscal impact to maintain contractual staff for the extended duration of the commission's work.
The Department of Labor oversees workforce development and adult learning programs, including correctional education programs, which are central to the commission's research and policy framework.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: DPSCS manages the state's correctional facilities and the adult offender population that is the subject of the commission's educational reform strategies.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly concerns the operational timeline, reporting requirements, and termination date of the Prison Education Delivery Reform Commission, which falls under this category of entity.

The commission's scope includes researching best practices for primary, secondary, and vocational education for those in the criminal and juvenile justice systems, which aligns with MSDE's oversight of educational policies and standards.
The bill's underlying commission is tasked with researching education for individuals subject to the juvenile justice system, which is the primary focus of DJS.
The commission is required to research and evaluate postsecondary education for those in the justice system, which is regulated and coordinated by MHEC.
The Governor's Office receives the commission's interim and final reports and oversees the Executive Branch departments (like GOCPP) that staff and support the commission.
DBM is the state's principal fiscal agency and will be involved in managing the general fund expenditures for the contractual staff needed to support the commission's extended lifecycle.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes the Task Force to Improve Attendance and Reduce Chronic Absenteeism in Schools to study and recommend strategies for identifying and preventing student absenteeism. The task force is tasked with analyzing attendance trends, setting a statewide reduction goal, and creating a toolkit for school leaders, while the Maryland State Department of Education must update regulations based on the task force's findings.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland State Department of Education
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland public school students, parents, teachers, school administrators, and local school systems.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The Maryland State Department of Education (MSDE) can implement the bill's requirements, including staffing the task force and updating regulations, using existing budgeted resources. State revenues are not affected. Local school systems may experience operational changes due to updated attendance regulations, but their finances are not expected to be materially affected.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: MSDE is the primary agency responsible for the task force. It must provide staff support, the State Superintendent appoints many of the members, and the department is mandated to update state regulations based on the task force's findings and distribute guidance and toolkits to local school systems.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill creates a new temporary Task Force to address student absenteeism, which falls under the definition of this collective entity of state commissions and task forces.
The Governor's Office is explicitly required to have a representative on the task force and will be a recipient of the final report and recommendations.

The task force is mandated to analyze statewide data and trends regarding chronic absenteeism and student attendance collection practices. MLDS is the state's central repository for linking and analyzing student and education data, making it a critical partner for the task force's research goals.

Reducing chronic absenteeism is directly aligned with this office's mission to promote child well-being and reduce child poverty. The task force's focus on nonpunitive and culturally responsive strategies is relevant to the GOC's mandate for comprehensive support networks.

The bill requires a school-based public health professional (such as a nurse) on the task force. As MDH oversees public health policy and school-based health initiatives, the task force's findings on health-related absences are relevant to their work.

Chronic absenteeism is often a symptom of housing, food, or family instability, areas managed by DHS. The task force's work on social support and nonpunitive interventions for students is highly relevant to DHS's role in delivering preventative aid to vulnerable children.

Chronic absenteeism is a key predictor of involvement with the juvenile justice system. DJS has a mission focus on rehabilitation and balancing public safety, making the prevention of absenteeism a relevant strategy for reducing future recidivism and delinquency.

The bill requires a representative from an institution of higher education to serve on the task force. As the state's coordinating board for higher education policy, the commission is a relevant stakeholder in ensuring these institutions are involved in absenteeism research.
The task force's goals align with the Innovation Team's priorities of reducing child poverty and enhancing economic mobility, as chronic absenteeism is a major barrier to these outcomes.

DBM oversees the state budget and personnel resources. The fiscal note specifies that MSDE must staff the task force using existing budgeted resources, which is a matter of budget execution monitored by DBM.
OAG provides legal counsel to state agencies. They would likely be involved in reviewing the new student attendance regulations that MSDE is required to adopt under Section 2 of the bill.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill phases in a requirement that all child support payments collected for a family participating in the Family Investment Program be passed through directly to the family and disregarded when calculating their assistance benefit amount. The pass-through percentage increases annually starting in fiscal year 2028 until reaching 100% in fiscal year 2031. Additionally, it prohibits local departments of social services from considering child support when computing supplemental nutrition benefits.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Human Services
qa_results.stakeholders: Families and children receiving assistance through the Family Investment Program, specifically those receiving Temporary Cash Assistance (TCA).
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: Starting in fiscal 2028, state general fund expenditures increase as child support collections previously used to offset program costs are passed to families. This impact grows to an estimated $13,900,000 annually by fiscal 2031. There is also a one-time expenditure of $406,100 in fiscal 2027 ($138,067 general funds and $268,013 federal funds) for required technology system upgrades to the Child Support Management and Eligibility and Enrollment systems.
