As the principal agency for veteran affairs, it is tasked with presenting state flags to families of deceased service members and is the primary subject of the bill's expanded 'veteran' and 'service member' definitions.
The bill modifies firearms licensing and permit exemptions for service members, requiring a $50,000 update to the agency's licensing portal according to the fiscal note.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill amends the Correctional Services Article to alter minimum age requirements and hiring exemptions for correctional officers who are veterans or members of the uniformed services.
The bill significantly impacts court operations by altering laws regarding court record fees, marriage license waiting periods, jury service exemptions, and judicial jurisdiction over CINA cases.
The bill amends the Family Law Article and foster care provisions specifically relating to out-of-home placement programs for former CINAs who serve in the uniformed services.
The bill explicitly amends the statutory definition and scope of 'emergency management' to clarify functions for which the expanded uniformed services are responsible.
The bill amends the Secretary's duties regarding the issuance of State flags to the families of deceased members of the uniformed services.
The OAG provides legal counsel to the impacted agencies and oversees consumer protection, which is relevant to the bill's provisions regarding the Servicemembers Civil Relief Act.
The bill's expanded definition of 'uniformed services' includes the Public Health Service (PHS), many of whose officers reside in Maryland and interface with state health initiatives.
The bill amends Real Property laws affecting residential lease liabilities and protections for service members who receive change of assignment orders.
The bill has a documented fiscal impact on state funds, specifically for the Maryland State Police portal updates, which falls under DBM's budget oversight.
The Governor's Office oversees the executive branch departments implementing these changes and is responsible for signing the legislation and coordinating military-related policy.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill clarifies that project site visits and educational field tours conducted by the Montgomery County Planning Board or the Washington Suburban Sanitary Commission (WSSC) do not constitute open meetings requiring live video or audio streaming, provided no organizational business is conducted. It also limits the requirement to live stream open meetings to those held at the entity's headquarters or a location where at least 10 meetings were held during the preceding calendar year.
qa_results.responsible_party: Montgomery County Planning Board and the Washington Suburban Sanitary Commission (WSSC)
qa_results.stakeholders: Montgomery County Planning Board, Washington Suburban Sanitary Commission (WSSC), and residents of Montgomery and Prince George's counties
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: According to the Fiscal Note, the bill has no state fiscal impact and does not materially affect the operations or finances of the Montgomery County Planning Board or the Washington Suburban Sanitary Commission.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Office of the Attorney General serves as the chief legal officer for the state and provides counsel on the implementation and enforcement of the Open Meetings Act. The agency was also a primary information source for the fiscal and policy analysis of this bill.

This bill directly amends the Land Use Article concerning the Montgomery County Planning Board. As the state agency responsible for coordinating land use planning and policy, the Department of Planning has a topical interest in the administrative procedures of regional planning boards.

The Governor's Office oversees the executive branch, coordinates policy initiatives, and is responsible for the final signing of legislation affecting the governance and transparency requirements of state-authorized boards and commissions.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill alters the membership of the Prince George’s County Board of Appeals by requiring the County Council to appoint at least three members, rather than exactly three, and changing the requirement for passing resolutions from a minimum of two members to a simple majority of the board.
qa_results.responsible_party: Prince George's County Council
qa_results.stakeholders: Residents of the regional district in Prince George’s County and the Prince George’s County Council.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: There is no State fiscal impact. Prince George’s County expenditures may increase starting in fiscal 2026 if the County Council chooses to appoint additional members to the board of appeals. The county’s fiscal 2025 budget for the board is $102,000, which includes $49,800 for stipends, $14,700 for fringe benefits, and $37,500 for operating expenses.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland Department of Planning is the state's principal agency for land use planning and provides technical assistance and policy guidance to local governments on the implementation of the Land Use Article. As this bill modifies the statutory membership and voting procedures for a local Board of Appeals established under that Article, it falls within the department's oversight of local planning and zoning governance.

This multi-agency initiative coordinates sustainable development and land use policies across state departments, including the Department of Planning. The administrative structure of local boards of appeals, which handle zoning variances and special exceptions, is relevant to the initiative's focus on effective local land use management.

The Office of the Attorney General provides legal counsel to the General Assembly and state agencies regarding the interpretation and enforcement of state laws. This bill amends the Land Use Article of the Annotated Code of Maryland, requiring legal oversight regarding its consistency with other state statutes.

The Maryland State Archives is responsible for maintaining the Maryland Manual On-Line, which provides the official record and description of state and local government boards and commissions. Structural changes to the Prince George's County Board of Appeals would require updates to these official records.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires the Commission on Behavioral Health Care Treatment and Access to establish a new workgroup focused on the improvement of health, social, and economic outcomes related to substance use. The workgroup is tasked with evaluating the availability and affordability of treatment and recovery services, the impact of criminal justice involvement on individuals with substance use disorders, the efficacy of voluntary versus mandated treatment, and the standards for discharging patients from substance use treatment programs.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health
qa_results.stakeholders: Individuals with substance use disorders, behavioral health treatment providers, criminal justice-involved individuals, and the Maryland Department of Health.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: Maryland Department of Health general fund expenditures increase by $38,000 in FY 2026 and $39,600 in FY 2027 to hire one part-time contractual health policy analyst to support the newly required workgroup. These costs cover salary, fringe benefits, and operating expenses. The fiscal impact ceases after FY 2027, as the Commission and its workgroups are scheduled to terminate on June 30, 2027. No local government fiscal impact is expected.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland Department of Health is the primary agency impacted. It is required to provide staff for the Commission, and the new workgroup is specifically tasked with evaluating MDH regulations regarding patient discharge from substance use treatment programs. The fiscal note indicates an expenditure increase of approximately $38,000 for MDH to hire a health policy analyst.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly relates to the mandates and structure of the Commission on Behavioral Health Care Treatment and Access, requiring it to establish a new specialized workgroup and defining its evaluative duties and reporting requirements.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The workgroup must evaluate the impact and costs of criminal justice involvement related to substance use, as well as the efficacy of mandated treatment versus voluntary treatment for individuals in the correctional system. The Secretary is also a member of the Commission.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: GOCPP is involved in the Commission's membership, and the workgroup's focus on mitigating harms from the criminalization of substance use aligns with the office's role in developing public safety and criminal justice strategies.

The Governor is responsible for appointing members to the Commission and designating its chair. Furthermore, several special secretaries within the Executive Department (e.g., Opioid Response) are statutory members of the Commission.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland Office of the Public Defender
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Office of the Public Defender is represented on the Commission and the workgroup is tasked with evaluating the impacts of criminal justice involvement on individuals, which directly concerns the indigent defendants represented by this agency.

The workgroup is required to evaluate individuals with experience in drug court programs and the efficacy of treatment mandated by the criminal justice system, which involves judicial operations and specialized court programs.
The workgroup will evaluate recovery support services including housing and employment, areas where DHS provides social service assistance. The Secretary is also a member of the Commission.
The Secretary of Juvenile Services is a member of the Commission, and the workgroup's focus on criminal justice-involved behavioral health includes youth under the jurisdiction of DJS.

The Special Secretary of the Governor's Office for Children is a member of the Commission. The workgroup's evaluation of social and economic outcomes related to substance use impacts the office's mission to reduce poverty and improve child well-being.

The workgroup is tasked with evaluating the affordability and accessibility of substance use treatment, which involves the regulation of health insurance carriers and benefit plans overseen by the MIA.
The Secretary of Aging is a member of the Commission, which maintains a workgroup specifically for geriatric behavioral health.
The Secretary of Disabilities is a member of the Commission, and the Commission oversees a workgroup focused on individuals with developmental disabilities and complex behavioral health needs.
DBM is responsible for the personnel and fiscal oversight related to the new contractual health policy analyst position required by the bill at the Department of Health.
The Executive Director of HSCRC is a member of the Commission, reflecting the workgroup's need to evaluate health outcomes and costs associated with hospital-based and inpatient treatment.
The Executive Director of MHCC is a member of the Commission, assisting with the evaluation of health outcomes and system-wide planning for behavioral health services.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill prohibits insurance carriers, including insurers, nonprofit health service plans, and health maintenance organizations, from including discretionary clauses in life insurance, health insurance, annuity, and health maintenance organization contracts. Discretionary clauses grant carriers the sole authority to interpret policy terms, which often limits judicial review to an 'abuse of discretion' standard. By banning these clauses, the bill ensures that courts can review benefit disputes using a 'de novo' standard, allowing for a more independent evaluation of claims.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Insurance Administration
qa_results.stakeholders: Insurance carriers (insurers, nonprofit health service plans, and health maintenance organizations) and Maryland residents with life, health, annuity, or HMO insurance policies.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The Maryland Insurance Administration (MIA) will experience a minimal increase in special fund revenue in FY 2026 resulting from $125 rate and form filing fees as carriers update their contracts. The MIA can implement the bill's requirements using its existing budgeted resources. There is no impact on local government finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland Insurance Administration is the primary regulator for the state's insurance market. The bill and fiscal note explicitly identify the MIA as the agency responsible for overseeing carrier compliance, processing rate and form filings, and collecting the associated filing fees for updated health, life, annuity, and disability policies.

The bill adds a specific provision to the Health - General Article (§ 19–706), which governs Health Maintenance Organizations (HMOs). As the department responsible for public health services and health policy, MDH has a significant interest in the regulatory standards applied to HMO contracts and health care financing.

The bill fundamentally changes the judicial standard of review in insurance litigation from an 'abuse of discretion' standard to a 'de novo' standard. This shift directly impacts how Maryland courts adjudicate cases where individuals have been denied benefits by insurance carriers or HMOs.

The OAG serves as the chief legal officer for the State and provides counsel to the MIA and MDH. Additionally, its Consumer Protection Division has a mandate to enforce state laws that protect residents from unfair practices in the insurance and healthcare industries, which is the core intent of prohibiting discretionary clauses.

DBM is the central personnel agency for the state, responsible for managing employee benefits, including health and life insurance plans. Any changes to the legal requirements for these policies would require DBM to ensure that the contracts provided to state employees do not contain prohibited discretionary clauses.

The MHBE administers the state's health insurance marketplace. Since the bill prohibits discretionary clauses in all health benefit plans issued or renewed in the state, the Exchange must ensure that the private health plans offered on its platform comply with the new contractual standards.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill repeals the requirement for the State and participating local governmental employers to pay separate administrative fees to the State Retirement and Pension System (SRPS). Instead, administrative and operational expenses for the system will be included in the employer contribution rates recommended by the actuary and certified by the Board of Trustees.
qa_results.responsible_party: Board of Trustees for the State Retirement and Pension System
qa_results.stakeholders: Participating employers of the State Retirement and Pension System, including Maryland State agencies, local school boards, community colleges, and participating local governmental units.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: In fiscal 2026, State Retirement Agency special fund revenues decrease by $21,800,000 and general fund expenditures decrease by $5,700,000. Local government expenditures also decrease by an estimated $21,800,000 in fiscal 2026. Beginning in fiscal 2027, the fiscal impact is expected to be neutral as the fee repeal is fully offset by higher normal employer contribution rates.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland State Retirement Agency (SRA) is directly responsible for the administration and operation of the retirement systems. This bill fundamentally alters its funding model by repealing administrative fees charged to employers and instead requiring these costs to be included in the actuarially determined employer contribution rates.

The Board of Trustees must certify the new employer contribution rates, which now include administrative expenses, to the Secretary of Budget and Management. DBM is the principal fiscal agency responsible for the state budget and managing personnel benefits, making it central to the bill's implementation.

The bill repeals the provision allowing the State Comptroller to exercise the right of setoff against money due to local employers who fail to pay administrative fees. The Comptroller also serves as the state's chief financial officer and a member of the Board of Public Works, which oversees fiscal integrity.

The Board of Trustees for the State Retirement and Pension System is required to certify employer contribution rates, including administrative expenses, to the Governor each year for the purpose of the annual state budget. The Governor also oversees the executive branch agencies impacted by this funding shift.

The Maryland State Treasurer's Office is the state's chief financial agency and the Treasurer serves as a key member of the Board of Trustees of the State Retirement and Pension System. The agency manages the state's funds and will oversee the revised methodology for funding retirement system operations.

The Office of the Attorney General serves as legal counsel to the Board of Trustees of the State Retirement and Pension System. The OAG will provide legal guidance on the repeal of administrative fee statutes and the transition to the new funding model for the system's operational expenses.

The Office of Legislative Audits conducts periodic fiscal compliance audits of the State Retirement Agency. The OLA will be responsible for evaluating the agency's compliance with the new funding mechanism and the appropriate use of the accumulation fund for operational expenses.

The bill repeals a specific statutory requirement that the State pay the pro rata share of administrative fees for each public library. This directly impacts the financial coordination and administrative funding structure for the Maryland State Library system.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires residential landlords to provide tenants with at least 24 hours' written notice before entering a leased premises, except in emergencies. It limits entry to between 7:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m., Monday through Saturday, unless otherwise agreed in writing. The bill authorizes tenants to seek court injunctions or damages for violations of these entry requirements.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Judiciary
qa_results.stakeholders: Residential tenants and landlords in Maryland
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is not anticipated to materially affect State or local government finances or operations. Small business impact is estimated to be minimal.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill establishes new legal requirements for landlord entry and specifically authorizes the court to issue injunctions and assess damages for violations. The Administrative Office of the Courts is responsible for supporting the judicial branch that will adjudicate these cases.

The Office of the Attorney General enforces consumer protection laws, which often include landlord-tenant relations. Additionally, they provide legal counsel to the state on housing policy and are cited as an information source for this legislation.

DHCD is the state's primary agency for housing-related policy and ensures residents have access to safe, secure housing. This legislation directly impacts the rights and protections of tenants across the state.
As the head of the executive branch, the Governor's Office oversees the enforcement of state laws and coordinates policy initiatives related to housing and tenant protections.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires the Governor to include at least $200 million in the annual operating or capital budget for site redevelopment and transportation infrastructure improvements for the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) headquarters relocation project. This mandate is triggered if the U.S. General Services Administration applies for a permit associated with relocating the FBI headquarters to Prince George’s County.
qa_results.responsible_party: The Governor of Maryland
qa_results.stakeholders: Prince George's County residents, the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), and the U.S. General Services Administration (GSA)
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill mandates an appropriation of at least $200,000,000 for the FBI headquarters relocation project. The fiscal note indicates the bill may have no additional fiscal effect if the $200,000,000 in General Obligation bond funding already authorized for the project satisfies the mandate. If interpreted as requiring additional funding, state expenditures could increase by $200,000,000 through the Transportation Trust Fund or additional bond authorizations.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly mandates that the Governor include a specific appropriation of at least $200 million in the annual operating or capital budget bill if certain conditions are met.
As the agency responsible for developing the state budget and supervising its execution, DBM is primary to implementing the $200 million mandated appropriation required by the bill.

The mandated funding is specifically for site redevelopment and transportation infrastructure improvements. The fiscal note indicates the project is already part of the Consolidated Transportation Program (CTP), which MDOT oversees.

The fiscal note identifies specific transportation improvements, such as an interchange along I-95/I-495 at the Greenbelt Metro Station, which falls under the direct jurisdiction and management of the State Highway Administration.

The Board of Public Works must approve significant state expenditures, capital projects, and the issuance of General Obligation bonds, all of which are involved in the $200 million project funding described in the bill and fiscal note.

The Treasurer's Office manages the state's General Obligation bond issuance and serves on the Board of Public Works. The fiscal note indicates that $200 million in GO bond funding is the primary mechanism for meeting the bill's mandate.
The Comptroller serves on the Board of Public Works, which must approve the contracts and bond issuances for this large-scale infrastructure project.

The relocation of the FBI headquarters is a major economic development initiative for the state. While Commerce is not the primary fiscal agent for the infrastructure, the project is central to its mission of attracting and retaining major employers.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill authorizes Maryland county and municipal governments to provide up to 30 days of paid disaster service leave to employees who are certified volunteers for organizations like the American Red Cross, Civil Air Patrol, or volunteer fire departments. It also permits local governments to offer paid leave for jury service, uniformed services training, subpoenaed court appearances, and specific administrative purposes.
qa_results.responsible_party: Local governmental units of counties and municipalities
qa_results.stakeholders: Employees of Maryland county and municipal governments
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no impact on State finances. Local government expenditures may increase, potentially significantly, due to costs for overtime and temporary coverage for employees taking additional paid leave. However, because the bill is authorizing rather than mandatory, the actual fiscal impact is dependent on the specific implementation decisions of individual local governmental units.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill provides leave for employees who are members of the Civil Air Patrol or the organized militia for training and active duty, both of which fall under the oversight and advisory mission of the Adjutant General and the Maryland Military Department.

The bill focuses on disaster service leave with pay for volunteers in organizations such as Maryland VOAD, CERT, and the Red Cross, all of which are coordinated by or support the mission of the Department of Emergency Management during disasters.

Local school systems are considered local governmental units in Maryland. The fiscal note highlights that this bill may significantly impact local expenditures for school systems like Frederick and Anne Arundel counties due to teacher coverage and payroll costs for employees on leave.

The bill authorizes leave for local employees to attend employee organization events and regulates aspects of personnel policy for local school system personnel, both of which fall under the PERB's jurisdiction regarding labor relations and collective bargaining.

The Department of Labor manages state-level leave programs and labor standards. The fiscal note specifically references the FAMLI program (Family and Medical Leave Insurance) as part of the broader policy context for this legislation.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Service and Civic Innovation
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This department is responsible for promoting service and volunteerism in Maryland. The bill incentivizes civic engagement and disaster service by authorizing paid leave for employees volunteering with emergency response organizations.
The department oversees local health departments whose employees would be affected by these local personnel policy changes; additionally, the agency was a source of information for the fiscal note.
The OAG provides legal counsel to the General Assembly and state agencies regarding the implementation and interpretation of local government and personnel laws.

As the head of the executive branch, the Governor signed the bill into law and oversees the administration of executive policy, including support for disaster response and intergovernmental relations with counties and municipalities.

qa_results.bill_summary: The bill establishes the State-Based Health Insurance Subsidies Program to provide financial assistance to individuals purchasing health insurance on the individual market. The program is specifically designed to mitigate the loss of affordability that would result from a reduction in federal advance premium tax credits (APTCs) in calendar years 2026 and 2027.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Health Benefit Exchange (MHBE)
qa_results.stakeholders: Individuals in Maryland purchasing health benefit plans through the individual insurance market and those currently receiving federal advance premium tax credits.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The Maryland Health Benefit Exchange (MHBE) special fund expenditures are estimated to increase by up to $75,000,000 in FY 2026, $150,000,000 in FY 2027, and $75,000,000 in FY 2028 to provide subsidies, provided federal tax credits are not extended. The program is funded through the MHBE Fund, including the 1% State health insurance provider fee assessment. If federal credits are extended, the bill and its associated costs terminate. There is no local fiscal impact.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill establishes the State-Based Health Insurance Subsidies Program and explicitly tasks the Maryland Health Benefit Exchange with its implementation, administration, and regulation.

The Insurance Commissioner must be consulted by the Exchange when establishing the program's eligibility and payment parameters. Additionally, the program is designed to impact rates in the individual insurance market, which the Administration regulates.

The bill requires the Exchange to consider uncertainties in enrollment in the Maryland Medical Assistance Program (Medicaid) when designing the subsidy program. Furthermore, the Maryland Health Benefit Exchange Fund provides funding for health programs administered by the Department.

The bill involves significant special fund expenditures (estimated up to $150 million annually) and references the budget amendment procedure, making it relevant to the state's principal fiscal and personnel agency.

The Governor oversees the executive branch, proposes the budget containing these appropriations, and has specific statutory duties regarding fund transfers related to the Health Benefit Exchange Fund.
The bill explicitly requires the Comptroller to account for the Maryland Health Benefit Exchange Fund.
The bill explicitly requires the State Treasurer to hold the Maryland Health Benefit Exchange Fund separately and invest its money.
The Office of the Attorney General provides legal counsel to the implementing agencies and would review the new regulations and program structures established by the bill.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires the Behavioral Health Advisory Council and the Commission on Behavioral Health Care Treatment and Access to develop recommendations for implementing federal Early and Periodic Screening, Diagnostic, and Treatment (EPSDT) requirements for children's behavioral health. The recommendations must address screening practices, diagnostic tools for children under age five, and community-based services to correct or ameliorate behavioral health conditions. The Maryland Department of Health is required to report these findings and recommendations to the General Assembly by January 1, 2026.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health, Behavioral Health Advisory Council, and the Commission on Behavioral Health Care Treatment and Access
qa_results.stakeholders: Medicaid-eligible children and youth under age 21, individuals with developmental disabilities or complex behavioral health needs, families and caregivers, and behavioral health care providers.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: According to the fiscal note, the Behavioral Health Advisory Council and the Commission on Behavioral Health Care Treatment and Access can provide the required recommendations and the Maryland Department of Health can submit the associated report with existing budgeted resources. The bill has no effect on state or local revenues.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland Department of Health administers the state's Medicaid program, which encompasses the Early and Periodic Screening, Diagnostic, and Treatment (EPSDT) requirements. The bill specifically requires the department to submit the final report of findings and recommendations to the General Assembly.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill explicitly tasks the Behavioral Health Advisory Council and the Commission on Behavioral Health Care Treatment and Access with providing the recommendations required for the implementation plan.

The bill mandates that the implementation recommendations address individuals with developmental disabilities, which directly aligns with the department's role in coordinating and improving services for residents with disabilities.
The office is focused on promoting the well-being of children and improving access to health services, which is the primary objective of enhancing the EPSDT screening and treatment framework.
The bill focuses on early childhood screening and behavioral health for children under age five, which overlaps with MSDE's oversight of early childhood development and special education services.
DHS serves vulnerable children and foster youth who are a priority population for EPSDT services, ensuring they receive the diagnostic and treatment services discussed in the bill.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill extends a property tax exemption to real property owned by nonprofit entities created by any public housing authority in Maryland, standardizing a tax treatment previously restricted to Baltimore City and Howard and Montgomery counties. It also mandates that these nonprofit entities enter into agreements with local governments for payments in lieu of taxes (PILOT).
qa_results.responsible_party: Public housing authorities and local political subdivisions
qa_results.stakeholders: Public housing authorities, nonprofit housing corporations, and low-income residents of Maryland housing projects.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: According to the Fiscal Note, there is a potential minimal decrease in State and local property tax revenues beginning in fiscal 2026. This impact depends on the extent to which public housing authorities establish these nonprofit entities. State and local expenditures are not expected to be significantly affected.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This bill directly amends the Housing and Community Development Article, modifying the tax-exempt status of nonprofit entities created by public housing authorities. DHCD is the primary agency responsible for affordable housing policy and community development in Maryland.

As the state's chief financial officer and tax collector, the Comptroller is responsible for monitoring tax exemptions and state revenues, which are impacted by the property tax exemptions standardized by this bill.

This agency adjudicates disputes over property tax exemptions. Expanding a property tax exemption to all nonprofit entities created by public housing authorities across the state directly affects the legal standards and cases they review.

The OAG provides legal counsel to state agencies like DHCD and the Comptroller and would be responsible for defending or interpreting the statutory definitions of 'housing authority entity' established by the bill.
DBM is responsible for revenue estimation and long-term fiscal planning. They must account for the projected decrease in State and local property tax revenues identified in the fiscal note.
The Tax Court serves as the highest administrative review for tax disputes, including appeals from PTAAB decisions regarding property tax exemptions for housing projects.

The Treasurer manages state funds, including the Annuity Bond Fund which is partially supported by state property tax revenue. Any impact on property tax receipts, however minimal, relates to their fiscal oversight role.
The Governor's Office oversees executive branch policy and signed the bill into law, as it aligns with broader executive priorities regarding housing affordability and administrative standardization.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland Medical Assistance Program (Medicaid) and private health insurance carriers to provide coverage for anesthesia for the entire duration of a medical procedure, including related care provided immediately before and after. It prohibits Medicaid and insurance carriers from establishing or enforcing any policies that place time limitations on the delivery of anesthesia.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health and Maryland Insurance Administration
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland residents enrolled in Medicaid or private health insurance, anesthesia providers, health insurance carriers, and managed care organizations
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: Medicaid expenditures are expected to increase by an indeterminate but minimal amount starting in fiscal year 2026, with the cost shared equally (50%) between state general funds and federal funds. Federal fund revenues will increase accordingly. The impact is primarily attributed to the removal of unit or time limits on certain anesthesia codes, such as dental anesthesia. No fiscal impact is expected for local governments or the State Employee and Retiree Health and Welfare Benefits Program.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland Department of Health (MDH) administers the Maryland Medical Assistance Program (Medicaid), which is explicitly required by the bill to provide coverage for the entire duration of anesthesia delivery and related care. The fiscal note indicates that Medicaid expenditures will increase as the agency must remove existing time limitations on certain dental anesthesia codes.

The Maryland Insurance Administration (MIA) is the primary regulator for the private insurance market. The bill adds Section 15-861 to the Insurance Article, creating a specific mandate that MIA must enforce, ensuring that insurers, HMOs, and nonprofit health service plans do not implement or enforce time limitations on anesthesia coverage.

The Maryland Health Benefit Exchange (MHBE) oversees the state's health insurance marketplace. The bill's mandates on private carriers apply to qualified health plans offered through the exchange, and the fiscal note discusses the bill's relationship with the State benchmark plan which MHBE manages.

The Office of the Attorney General (OAG) provides legal counsel to the Department of Health and the Maryland Insurance Administration. It is responsible for advising these agencies on the implementation and enforcement of the new statutory requirements regarding health coverage.

The Department of Budget and Management (DBM) oversees the State Employee and Retiree Health and Welfare Benefits Program. While the fiscal note indicates no significant fiscal impact on the program, the department is relevant as it manages the state's employee health plans which are subject to review for compliance with state insurance mandates.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill prohibits health insurance carriers, including nonprofit health service plans and health maintenance organizations, from requiring patients to use a step therapy or fail-first protocol for FDA-approved prescription drugs used to treat symptoms or side effects of stage four advanced metastatic cancer. To qualify for this prohibition, the drug must be prescribed by a treating physician, be consistent with best practices and peer-reviewed medical literature, and be a covered benefit under the patient's insurance policy.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Insurance Administration
qa_results.stakeholders: Patients with stage four advanced metastatic cancer, treating physicians, health insurance carriers, nonprofit health service plans, health maintenance organizations, and pharmacy benefits managers.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State special fund revenue for the Maryland Insurance Administration is expected to increase minimally in FY 2026 due to the $125 rate and form filing fee. The bill is not expected to impact the State Employee and Retiree Health and Welfare Benefits Program. Fiscal impact on local governments with fully insured health benefit plans is estimated to be minimal.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland Insurance Administration is the primary regulator of the state's insurance market. The bill requires the MIA to review rate and form filings from insurers, nonprofit health service plans, and health maintenance organizations to ensure compliance with the new step therapy prohibitions.

DBM is the central personnel agency for the state and manages the State Employee and Retiree Health and Welfare Benefits Program. While the fiscal note currently assumes no likely impact, the department must monitor the bill's requirements for potential changes to the state's healthcare plan coverage and costs.

The Maryland Department of Health sets overall state health policy and was consulted as an information source for the bill's fiscal impact. Changes to cancer treatment protocols and drug coverage standards intersect with the department's public health mission.

The OAG serves as the legal counsel for all state agencies, including the Maryland Insurance Administration. It may be required to provide legal guidance on the interpretation and enforcement of the new insurance mandates.

As the head of the executive branch, the Governor's Office oversees the departments implementing the bill (MIA and DBM) and is responsible for signing the legislation and coordinating the policy initiatives it represents.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill expands the existing beauty salon beer and wine license in Montgomery County to include barbershops and authorizes the license holder to provide liquor in addition to beer and wine. It increases the allowable amount of beer from 5 ounces to 12 ounces and sets a limit of 1.7 ounces for liquor per customer for on-premises consumption while receiving services or attending specific fundraising events.
qa_results.responsible_party: Montgomery County Board of License Commissioners
qa_results.stakeholders: Beauty salon and barbershop owners and customers in Montgomery County
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: According to the Fiscal Note, there is no state fiscal impact. Montgomery County revenues are not affected, and the county can manage any additional enforcement activity with existing resources. The annual license fee is $100.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Comptroller of Maryland is responsible for regulating the alcohol industry and enforcing state tax laws. Although this bill focuses on Montgomery County, changes to alcoholic beverages licenses and consumption limits fall under the agency's broader regulatory and revenue collection oversight.

The bill expands alcoholic beverage licensing eligibility to holders of barbershop and beauty salon permits. These professions and their associated permits are licensed and regulated by boards housed within the Maryland Department of Labor under the Business Occupations and Professions Article.

As the head of the executive branch, the Governor's Office is responsible for the final approval and signing of the bill, as well as overseeing the implementation of state laws by relevant departments.

The Office of the Attorney General provides legal counsel to the General Assembly and state agencies. It may be involved in reviewing the bill for legal sufficiency and ensuring that the expansion of alcohol licenses complies with state law.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland Automobile Insurance Fund (MAIF) to calculate and report its risk-based capital (RBC) levels and maintain total adjusted capital above a specific threshold. It transitions MAIF from a 'file and use' ratemaking process to a 'prior approval' process during certain periods. Additionally, it requires the Maryland Insurance Administration to establish a workgroup to study the affordability of private passenger automobile insurance in the State.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Insurance Administration and the Maryland Automobile Insurance Fund
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland Automobile Insurance Fund (MAIF) policyholders, private passenger automobile insurers, insurance producers, and Maryland drivers.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The Maryland Insurance Administration (MIA) can implement the bill's requirements using existing budgeted resources. The Maryland Automobile Insurance Fund's (MAIF) nonbudgeted revenues may be impacted to the extent that new capital requirements force a shift from equity investments to lower-risk, lower-yield fixed-income investments, potentially reducing investment income and increasing the likelihood or amount of future assessments on policyholders. Specific dollar estimates for these impacts are not provided in the fiscal note.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the primary subject of the bill, MAIF is required to calculate and report risk-based capital levels, maintain specific adjusted capital levels, and transition to prior approval rate-making standards under certain circumstances. Its Executive Director also serves on the affordability study workgroup.

MIA is the primary regulator responsible for overseeing MAIF's new capital reporting, reviewing the adequacy of its capital plans, and chairing the workgroup established to study automobile insurance affordability.
The bill references the Motor Vehicle Administration's role in arranging for the collection of premiums on policies issued by MAIF and requires those funds to be deposited with the State Treasurer.
The bill specifies that premiums collected by the Motor Vehicle Administration on behalf of MAIF must be paid to the State Treasurer for the account of the fund.
The Governor receives the final report from the affordability study workgroup and oversees the executive agencies (MIA and MDOT/MVA) involved in the bill's implementation.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill establishes a temporary workgroup composed of state officials and private stakeholders to conduct a specific study on automobile insurance affordability and report its findings.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland Department of Health, in collaboration with the Commission on Health Equity, to develop and maintain a public health equity data dashboard. The dashboard must provide age-adjusted health disparity data disaggregated by race, ethnicity, and gender for various health indicators, including chronic diseases, mental health, and health insurance access, and must be updated on a quarterly basis.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health and the Maryland Commission on Health Equity
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland residents and public health organizations focused on racial, ethnic, and gender-based health disparities.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: According to the Fiscal Note, the Maryland Department of Health and the Maryland Commission on Health Equity can develop and update the required health equity data dashboard using existing budgeted resources. The bill has no impact on state revenues or local government finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This independent agency within the Department of Health is responsible for planning for health system needs and improving access to care. The data dashboard's focus on health indicators and disparities is directly relevant to their regulatory and planning functions.
The dashboard is required to include information regarding health insurance access, which is the primary mission of the Exchange as the administrator of the state's health insurance marketplace.
This agency promotes equity in healthcare financing and population health outcomes; the dashboard provides essential data to track these metrics across hospitals and regions.

The agency utilizes data-driven strategies and performance metrics to enhance state government responsiveness; a statewide health equity dashboard serves as a critical performance monitoring tool for executive branch priorities.

The Governor's Office oversees the executive branch and coordinates policy initiatives; this bill establishes a new administrative requirement for a principal department (MDH) to report data on public health equity.
The bill designates the Maryland Department of Health as the primary agency responsible for developing, hosting, updating, and publishing the health equity data dashboard.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Commission on Health Equity, which falls under this category, is specifically mandated by the bill to collaborate with the Department of Health to develop the data dashboard.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes the Population Health Improvement Fund to support Maryland's participation in the federal States Advancing All-Payer Health Equity Approaches and Development (AHEAD) Model. It authorizes the Health Services Cost Review Commission to assess hospital rates to fund initiatives aimed at reducing preventable health conditions and health disparities, allows for the use of electronic health care transaction data for public health purposes, and establishes reporting and legislative oversight requirements.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health and the Health Services Cost Review Commission
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland hospitals, healthcare patients, Medicaid recipients, and the Maryland Department of Health.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: According to the fiscal note, special fund revenues and expenditures will increase by $25,000,000 in fiscal 2026 due to a hospital rate assessment. Medicaid expenditures are projected to increase by $5,000,000 ($2,000,000 in general funds and $3,000,000 in federal funds) to cover these higher rates. The assessment authority for hospital rates is set to expire on December 31, 2027, and the fund itself sunsets at the end of 2030.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland Department of Health (MDH) is the primary agency responsible for implementing the AHEAD Model. The bill tasks MDH with jointly administering the Population Health Improvement Fund, providing annual reports to the General Assembly, and coordinating monthly updates with legislative members regarding the model's progress.

The HSCRC is a key implementing agency for the AHEAD Model. It is authorized to assess hospital rates to generate revenue for the Population Health Improvement Fund and jointly administers the fund with MDH. It is also required to participate in monthly legislative briefings and coordinate implementation with federal partners.

The MHCC oversees the regulations governing electronic health care transactions and the state-designated health information exchange (CRISP). The bill explicitly clarifies that MHCC regulations must allow the use of this data for the AHEAD Model and successor health equity initiatives.

The bill creates the Population Health Improvement Fund as a special, nonlapsing fund. The State Treasurer is responsible for holding the fund separately and investing its money, with interest earnings credited back to the fund or the General Fund depending on the fiscal year.
As the state's chief financial officer, the Comptroller is responsible for accounting for the new Population Health Improvement Fund and ensuring proper accrual of interest earnings.
The bill explicitly mandates that the newly established Population Health Improvement Fund is subject to audit by the Office of Legislative Audits.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland Commission on Health Equity (MCHE) is designated as the governance body for the AHEAD Model. This commission will develop the Statewide Health Equity Plan (SHEP), which dictates how the Population Health Improvement Fund's expenditures are utilized.

The Governor's Office negotiated and entered into the agreement with the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) for the AHEAD Model. The Governor also oversees the agencies (MDH and HSCRC) implementing the policy and coordinates the underlying state budget priorities.

DBM oversees the development and execution of the state budget. The bill impacts state expenditures, particularly through the creation of a new special fund and the associated impact on Medicaid spending (general and federal funds) resulting from hospital rate assessments.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill increases the minimum age from 16 to 18 for individuals employed by alcoholic beverages license holders in Allegany County, unless the license holder derives more than 50% of its revenue from food sales, in which case the minimum age remains 16.
qa_results.responsible_party: Allegany County Board of License Commissioners
qa_results.stakeholders: Alcoholic beverages license holders and individuals between the ages of 16 and 18 in Allegany County seeking employment at these establishments.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no effect on State finances and does not materially affect Allegany County operations or finances. The fiscal impact on small businesses is expected to be minimal.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Comptroller of Maryland is the primary state-level agency responsible for regulating the alcohol industry. This bill amends the Alcoholic Beverages and Cannabis Article to alter employment age requirements for alcoholic beverages license holders in Allegany County, directly impacting the regulatory framework the Comptroller oversees.

The Maryland Department of Labor is responsible for enforcing workplace safety and labor laws. This bill modifies the minimum age for employment within a specific industry (alcoholic beverages) in Allegany County, which relates to the department's mission to protect workers and regulate employment practices.

The Office of the Attorney General serves as the chief legal officer for the state and provides counsel to state agencies and the General Assembly. They would be responsible for interpreting the legal application of these changes to the Alcoholic Beverages and Cannabis Article and providing guidance on enforcement.

The Governor's Office oversees the executive branch and coordinates policy initiatives. As the Governor signed this bill into law, the office is responsible for the overall execution of state law and the appointment of various officials that may overlap with local liquor board oversight.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill expands the Small Solar Energy Generating System Incentive Program to include solar energy generating systems with capacities between 20 kilowatts and 5 megawatts that are located on or over water retention ponds or quarries currently or previously designated for industrial use. It also authorizes local governments to grant a property tax credit for nonresidential solar energy generating systems constructed on brownfields, water retention ponds, or quarries.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Public Service Commission
qa_results.stakeholders: Nonresidential solar energy developers, local government jurisdictions, and owners of industrial properties, quarries, or water retention ponds.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State: The Public Service Commission, State Department of Assessments and Taxation, and Maryland Department of the Environment can implement the bill with existing resources, and State revenues are not materially affected. Local: Local property tax revenues may decrease beginning in fiscal 2026 to the extent that counties or municipalities choose to grant the authorized property tax credits. The specific local impact is indeterminate and depends on local adoption and the number/value of eligible solar systems.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill expands the Small Solar Energy Generating System Incentive Program, which is established and administered by the Public Service Commission (PSC). PSC is responsible for certifying systems and determining eligibility under the program.

The bill targets solar systems on brownfields, industrial water retention ponds, and quarries. MDE regulates brownfields, closed landfills, and industrial activities at these sites, and oversees the conservation of wetlands and waterways where floating solar systems may be located.

MEA is responsible for maximizing energy efficiency and promoting renewable energy. It provides expertise on solar incentives and conducted the assessment of landfills and brownfields for solar development mentioned in the fiscal note.

As the state's green bank, MCEC is tasked with advancing clean energy technologies. The bill's support for innovative solar siting (floating systems and brownfields) aligns with MCEC's mission to provide financing and support for energy projects.

The Department of Planning promotes sustainable growth and land use. The siting of solar energy generating systems on industrial and non-traditional sites like quarries and brownfields involves state and local land use coordination.

The bill authorizes local governments to grant property tax credits for nonresidential solar systems. PTAAB is the independent agency responsible for hearing appeals regarding property tax assessments and credits.

MES provides technical and operational environmental services for industrial and waste sites. The agency was involved in assessing the suitability of landfills and industrial sites for solar energy development as cited in the fiscal note.

MEDCO assists in the retention and expansion of business and industry. The bill encourages the reuse of brownfields and industrial sites (quarries) for solar energy, which supports economic revitalization and infrastructure development.

This multi-agency initiative promotes sustainable development and coordinates efforts to reduce the state's carbon footprint. Expanding solar generation on marginalized lands like brownfields is a core objective of the initiative.
The Governor's Office oversees policy initiatives and sets the state's renewable energy and climate goals, which are directly advanced by the expansion of solar energy generating systems.
The OAG provides legal counsel to the Public Service Commission, the Department of the Environment, and other state agencies involved in regulating and certifying these solar energy systems.

DNR manages Maryland's natural resources and waterways. While the bill focuses on industrial ponds, the placement of floating systems may interact with broader natural resource management and conservation policies.
The Maryland Tax Court is the highest level of administrative review for tax disputes and would hear appeals related to the property tax credits authorized by this bill.

The Department of Commerce is interested in the economic vitality of Maryland's industrial sectors. The bill's incentives for solar energy on brownfields and quarries promote the productive reuse of industrial land.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes a program within the Maryland State Department of Education (MSDE) to help parenting foster youth access child care subsidies for their children by removing various application barriers. The program eliminates requirements for proof of employment or enrollment in education, the name of the other parent, and income information related to foster parents. Eligible foster youth, aged 16 to 21, are also exempt from child care copays under this scholarship program.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland State Department of Education
qa_results.stakeholders: Parenting foster youth between the ages of 16 and 21 who are or were in the state's out-of-home care system, and their children.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund expenditures increase by $91,000 in fiscal 2026 only for MSDE to perform necessary system reprogramming. General fund expenditures further increase, potentially significantly, beginning in fiscal 2026 as additional families become eligible for the Child Care Scholarship Program; the Fiscal Note provides an illustrative annual increase of $355,680 based on 30 participating families. There is no impact on local government finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: MSDE is the primary agency responsible for administering the Child Care Scholarship Program and the new Youth Transitioning From Foster Placement to Successful Adulthood Program. The bill requires MSDE to remove application barriers, update tracking systems, and report annually on the program's progress.

DHS is responsible for the foster youth population targeted by this bill. The bill specifically mandates that DHS make referrals to MSDE regarding the program for youth in or transitioning from out-of-home care.

The bill has a notable fiscal impact, requiring general fund expenditures for system reprogramming ($91,000) and ongoing scholarship costs for newly eligible participants. DBM oversees the state's budget and fiscal planning affected by these expenditures.

This agency's mission includes reducing child poverty and supporting vulnerable youth and families. The program directly addresses child care access for parenting foster youth, aligning with the office's core policy objectives.
The Governor's Office oversees the executive branch agencies implementing this program (MSDE and DHS) and coordinates the policy initiatives related to child care and foster youth transitions.

The OAG provides legal counsel to MSDE and DHS. Implementing the new program and removing specific application requirements like 'the name of the other parent' may require legal guidance and regulatory updates.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill increases the maximum number of members on the Office of Child Care Advisory Council from 30 to 31 and adds a representative from the Maryland Association of Public Library Administrators to the council's membership.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland State Department of Education
qa_results.stakeholders: Members of the Office of Child Care Advisory Council, the Maryland Association of Public Library Administrators, and the Maryland child care community.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill does not materially affect State finances or operations, and there is no local fiscal impact according to the fiscal note.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland State Department of Education (MSDE) oversees the Office of Child Care and its Early Childhood Development Division. This bill directly alters the composition of the Office of Child Care Advisory Council, which advises the department, and assigns appointment responsibilities to the State Superintendent of Schools.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill's primary purpose is to alter the membership and statutory cap of the Office of Child Care Advisory Council, which is a state advisory body categorized under this entity.

The bill adds a representative from the Maryland Association of Public Library Administrators to the Council. This expands the role of the public library systems, which are lead and coordinated by the Maryland State Library Agency, in state child care policy.

The Maryland Department of Health is a statutory member of the Office of Child Care Advisory Council, and its participation is part of the council's interagency coordination being modified by this bill.
The Department of the Environment is a statutory member of the Office of Child Care Advisory Council, which is the subject of this bill's membership alterations.
The Office of the State Fire Marshal is a statutory member of the Council. In Maryland, the State Fire Marshal's Office is a division of the Department of State Police.
The Council includes representation from the Maryland Association of Social Services Directors, who lead the local departments of social services that function under the Department of Human Services.

The Council includes representation from community colleges with early childhood education programs, which fall under the regulatory and coordinating oversight of the Maryland Higher Education Commission.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill modifies the criteria and procedures for medical and geriatric parole in Maryland. It requires the Maryland Parole Commission to consider an individual's age when evaluating parole suitability, removes the Governor's authority to veto medical parole for individuals serving life sentences, and establishes a specific 'geriatric parole' process for incarcerated individuals aged 65 or older who have served at least 20 years. It also mandates that the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services regularly identify and submit eligible names to the Commission for risk assessments and hearings.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Parole Commission and the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
qa_results.stakeholders: Incarcerated individuals (specifically those 65 or older or those with terminal or chronic medical conditions), crime victims, and the Maryland Parole Commission.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund expenditures increase by $474,500 in FY 2026, rising to approximately $654,500 by FY 2030, primarily to hire psychologists for risk assessments and administrative staff. These costs may be partially offset by potential savings in incarceration costs (estimated at $5,339 per month per individual), though the total savings are indeterminate. The Justice Reinvestment Oversight Board may also recommend redirecting annual savings to fund these assessments. There is no material impact on local finances.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The department is the primary agency responsible for implementing the bill, as it oversees the Maryland Parole Commission and the Division of Correction, which are tasked with identifying eligible individuals, conducting risk assessments, holding geriatric and medical parole hearings, and managing the associated fiscal savings.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The office manages the Performance Incentive Grant Fund and supports the Justice Reinvestment Oversight Board, which is authorized by the bill to recommend that state savings be distributed to the Parole Commission for hiring psychologists to perform risk assessments.

The bill repeals the Governor's specific statutory authority to disapprove decisions by the Maryland Parole Commission regarding the granting of medical parole to incarcerated individuals serving life sentences.

The bill has a notable fiscal impact requiring the department to oversee the creation of four new positions (psychologists and administrative staff) and manage the resulting general fund expenditure increases.

The office provides primary legal counsel to the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services and the Parole Commission, and will be involved in drafting the new regulations and ensuring the legal implementation of the revised parole standards.

The bill requires determinations by licensed physicians regarding terminal illness and chronic debility and shifts the healthcare management of parolees to community-based health care services regulated or funded by the department.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This entity encompasses the Justice Reinvestment Oversight Board, which is specifically tasked with monitoring parole outcomes and recommending the distribution of savings to the Parole Commission.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill authorizes the Maryland Department of the Environment (MDE) to establish a privatization program for well and on-site sewage disposal system activities in Dorchester County upon request. It requires MDE to oversee the program, conduct audits, and ensure consumer protections, while limiting participation to licensed environmental health specialists.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of the Environment
qa_results.stakeholders: Residents and businesses in Dorchester County, licensed environmental health specialists, and the Dorchester County Health Department.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: According to the Fiscal Note, State general fund expenditures increase by $96,000 in FY 2026 for a contractual sanitarian to manage the program, with costs continuing through FY 2028. Local revenue and expenditure impacts for Dorchester County are indeterminate, as they depend on the specific implementation of the privatization program and its effect on health department fees and staffing.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the primary implementing agency, MDE is authorized to establish the privatization program, set its regulations, conduct mandatory compliance audits, and manage the delegation of well and on-site sewage disposal authority in Dorchester County.

Local health departments (LHDs) act as the 'delegated approval authority' for well and septic activities in Maryland. The Dorchester County Health Department, which operates under MDH, is specifically tasked with reviewing and approving work performed under this privatization program.

The fiscal note indicates a need for general fund expenditures to hire a contractual sanitarian to manage and audit the program. DBM oversees the state's personnel and budget execution necessary for this staffing.

The bill explicitly requires the privatization program to comply with applicable procurement laws. DGS serves as the central procurement authority for the state and oversees the standards for such contracts.

OAG provides legal counsel to state agencies like MDE and will be involved in drafting regulations, reviewing procurement compliance, and advising on consumer protection and ethics standards mandated by the bill.

The bill mandates that MDE establish appropriate ethics policies, including conflict of interest standards, for the privatization program, which falls within the Commission's general domain of ensuring state government integrity.

The bill addresses a specific administrative challenge in Dorchester County, a rural jurisdiction. The Council is responsible for advocating for rural interests and assisting with regional challenges like the ones addressed by this privatization effort.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland State Board of Contract Appeals
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: Since the program must follow state procurement laws, the MSBCA would be the body responsible for adjudicating any bid protests or contract disputes that arise during the privatization process.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Small, Minority & Women Business Affairs
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The privatization program must comply with state procurement laws, which includes implementing and monitoring socioeconomic programs like the Minority Business Enterprise (MBE) and Small Business Reserve (SBR) programs.
As the body that oversees significant state contracts and procurement, the BPW may be required to approve the resulting contracts or agreements established under MDE's privatization program.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill expands the duties of the Workgroup on Home Detention Monitoring to include studying policies and responses to violations of home detention, such as absconding. It also requires the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services to collect and report annual data to the Workgroup regarding the demographics of participants, the number and nature of violations, and whether those violations were reported to law enforcement or judges.
qa_results.responsible_party: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
qa_results.stakeholders: Individuals on home detention monitoring, private and public home detention monitoring agencies, law enforcement agencies, and the Judiciary.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services can implement the bill's data collection and reporting requirements using existing resources. State revenues are not affected, and there is no anticipated material fiscal impact on local government finances.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services (DPSCS) is the primary agency impacted by the bill. It is required to provide staff for the Workgroup and must annually collect and report detailed data on home detention monitoring and violations.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly modifies the mandate, study requirements, and data collection duties of the Workgroup on Home Detention Monitoring, which is a state workgroup composed of appointed members.

The Judiciary is represented on the Workgroup by a representative appointed by the Chief Justice. Additionally, the bill mandates data collection regarding the number of times home detention violations are reported to judges.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland Office of the Public Defender
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Public Defender of Maryland, or their designee, is a statutory member of the Workgroup. The bill's focus on home detention monitoring policies and data disaggregated by race and gender is highly relevant to the agency's advocacy for indigent defendants.

The Governor's Office is responsible for appointing seven different members to the Workgroup, including representatives from local detention centers, pretrial programs, and private monitoring agencies.

The Office of the Attorney General provides legal counsel to the state agencies involved, including DPSCS and the Judiciary, and may be involved in advising on the legal implications of the workgroup's recommendations.
The Department of Budget and Management oversees the state budget which provides for the reimbursement of expenses for Workgroup members under the Standard State Travel Regulations.

The bill requires tracking the number of home detention violations reported to law enforcement. Additionally, the Governor appoints a representative from the Maryland Chiefs of Police Association to the workgroup.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes the Child Support Arrearage to Work Pilot Program within the Maryland Department of Labor to connect unemployed individuals who are in arrears on child support with employment opportunities, including positions within State government.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Labor
qa_results.stakeholders: Unemployed individuals in arrears under a child support order and Maryland State government agencies.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund expenditures for the Maryland Department of Labor may increase by as much as $156,600 in fiscal 2026 for contractual staff to implement the program. The bill is not expected to materially affect local government finances or the Unemployment Insurance Trust Fund.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Department of Labor is the primary agency responsible for establishing, implementing, and reporting on the Child Support Arrearage to Work Pilot Program. Its Division of Workforce Development and Adult Learning (DWDAL) will specifically manage the pilot to connect unemployed individuals in arrears with employment opportunities.

The Department of Labor must consult with the Department of Human Services to implement the program. DHS oversees the Child Support Administration, which manages the records of individuals in arrears and will likely be the source of participant data for the pilot.

The Department of Labor must consult with DBM to implement the program. DBM is the state's central personnel agency, and the bill specifically includes connecting participants with employment opportunities within State government, which falls under DBM's purview.

The GWDB is the governor's chief policy-making body for the state's workforce system. This pilot program represents a workforce solution targeting a specific demographic (unemployed individuals in child support arrears) and aligns with the board's mission to create pathways to prosperity.

The Governor is responsible for overseeing the executive branch agencies implementing the pilot. Additionally, the Department of Labor is required to submit a report on the program's findings and recommendations to the Governor by July 1, 2026.

The OAG provides legal counsel to the agencies involved. It will likely be involved in developing the 'procedures and safeguards' required by the bill to securely share sensitive information related to child support arrears and program participants.

The Innovation Team is charged with piloting novel initiatives to reduce child poverty and enhance economic mobility. This pilot program directly aligns with those priorities by addressing child support arrears through employment.

The GOC focuses on reducing child poverty. Because child support payments are a critical factor in child well-being and poverty reduction, this pilot program's success in increasing payments through employment is relevant to the office's mission.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes the Buprenorphine Training Grant Program within the Maryland Department of Health to help counties offset the costs of training paramedics to administer buprenorphine. It also mandates that the Maryland Office of Overdose Response convene a workgroup to study access to buprenorphine in the state and report findings and recommendations to the Governor and General Assembly.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health and the Maryland Office of Overdose Response
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland counties, paramedics, and individuals with opioid use disorders.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill mandates an annual appropriation of at least $50,000 from the Opioid Restitution Fund between fiscal 2027 and 2031 for the grant program. In fiscal 2026, general fund expenditures increase by $56,100 for the Maryland Office of Overdose Response to hire contractual personnel for a workgroup. Local governments may see an increase in revenues and expenditures to the extent they receive grants.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill establishes the Buprenorphine Training Grant Program within the Department of Health (MDH). Additionally, the Behavioral Health Administration and the Maryland Office of Overdose Response (which is nested within or closely affiliated with MDH) are key participants in the mandated workgroup and reporting process.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland Institute for Emergency Medical Services Systems
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The agency is specifically named as a required member of the workgroup to study buprenorphine access. Furthermore, the bill's primary goal is to fund the training of paramedics to administer buprenorphine, and paramedics fall under the regulatory and coordination oversight of MIEMSS.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill creates a new workgroup to study and report on buprenorphine access in the State. It also involves the Opioid Restitution Fund Advisory Council, which must approve certain uses of the fund from which the grant program is financed.

The Maryland Office of Overdose Response (MOOR), an executive office, is charged with convening the workgroup and submitting a report to the Governor. The Governor is also mandated to include an annual appropriation of at least $50,000 for the grant program in the budget bill.

DBM is responsible for the state's budget and personnel. The bill mandates a recurring appropriation from the Opioid Restitution Fund and, according to the fiscal note, requires the hiring of contractual personnel to staff the workgroup.
The State Treasurer's Office is the custodian of the Opioid Restitution Fund, which is the funding source for the new Buprenorphine Training Grant Program established by the bill.
The Comptroller is responsible for accounting for the Opioid Restitution Fund and managing the disbursement of revenues for the grant program established by the bill.

The MHCC is responsible for planning for health system needs and improving access to care. The bill's workgroup is tasked with identifying geographic gaps in buprenorphine services and provider capacity, which aligns with MHCC's core mission.
